Ellis Hollow Yellow trail.Name: Ellis Hollow Yellow trail
Ellis Hollow Yellow trail.Description: Need a break from the hassles of everyday life?  A walk through the fern-carpeted forests of the Ellis Hollow Nature Preserve could be just the thing.  In winter, take your cross-country skis to enjoy one of the peaceful, snow-covered loop trails.  Just a short drive from downtown Ithaca, this 150-acre preserve on the northern hillside of the Ellis Hollow valley has 2 miles of hiking trails. The parking area and initial stretch of trail gives no hint of what's to come.  After 500 feet you will find an informational kiosk which marks the junction where the trail splits into a series of nested loops.  Starting to the left will take you along a stream and through a forest where shady eastern hemlock often dominates.  The path on the right winds up and around a somewhat terraced hillside through a mixed hardwood forest.  In the spring and summer, the preserve's quiet, steepsided glens provide visitors with spectacular birding opportunities.   The streams running through the preserve drain into Cascadilla Creek, and are important for maintaining the water quality in the creek and nearby wetlands.

parking lot: Small Parking lot at trailhead

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Good loop trail system with varied terrain and lots of tree variety.
nice easy trail. beautiful woods. lightly trafficked. in autumn, leaves on trails can hide roots that one can easily trip over.

I did this hike backward and I found a few spots difficult to navigate, especially at one point there is a road and someone's driveway, it got a little confusing. There were a lot of good inclines, but following this trail, my hike was about a mile longer than what it says on alltrails.

Great hike with well marked paths in a wooded area. We went in the morning and it wasn't nearly as popular as other hikes in the area.  There are a couple different routes to follow. Going clockwise, the 1.6 mile loop follows the yellow tail, then blue trail, then red trail.
Nice hike in the woods. Dogs are welcome- not sure why it says no dogs on the app. Some steep areas and lots of roots. Well marked and maintained. A few cute creeks.
Definitely a favorite! So many frogs and salamanders today. We usually go clockwise but I think I like this way better.
Great short trail. Lots of ups and downs and little creek crossings. Kind of a drag when the energy plant is being noisy, but that is rare.
A very peaceful, secluded spot. It's not crowded, even on weekends. Even though the loop is short, there are steep slopes that make it somewhat challenging.
Nice trail, great for kids if you follow the “Story book” trail. A book to read and creek to get feet wet..  my kids love it!
Great loop trail, however if you follow the red trail, which is part of this loop, I would rate it as moderate. Well marked, enjoy the stream crossings.
Fun walk in the woods with some minor climbs. Mostly peaceful, some brooks to cross although most were dry when we were here (July). Good place for a run. Nothing mind blowing, but good solitude.

Friends and I took our kids, including a four and a six year old, on a warmish day in January. There was enough mud, stream crossings, and slippery leaf cover on steepish slopes to make the trail feel kid unfriendly. It was a little much for them, but I think that wouldn’t be the case in the drier summer and fall months when the ground would be easier to walk upon. I found it a great trail myself, perfect for taking a decent yet not-too-long walk without having to backtrack.

We stumbled across this site using All Trails and were glad we did. We were in the area and looking for a short trail run and hike and this was perfect. It is a quiet forested area with opportunities for wildlife and peace. A local poet has posted some of their works throughout the system which was neat too. The main loop is about 1.5 miles and there are two shorter loops so you can easily cover about 3 miles or so if you do all three. We spotted a large owl and some neat salamanders/newts on our run. The trail is well marked and easy for trail running. There is a little elevation gain as well.  Would definitely go back if we are ever in the area again.
One my most favorite spots to just unwind. Would recommend this one to anyone

An excellent trail that is usually not busy.  You start with a strange walk alongside the power plant, but quickly dive into the trees and can enjoy the quiet babbling of the creek running next to the trail.  There are a couple different sized loops and they are minimally strenuous, but there are a couple good, short climbs that can get your heart rate up.  I would definitely recommend this hike, especially around sunset.

Unlike Eldridge Nature Preserve in which I got lost last time and which has the similar trail length as this one.. the trail was well-marked and it was obvious that a lot of people use this trail.  I didn't come across with anyone however, only one extra car in the parking area.  That car was gone by the time I came out of the forest.  It's a nice quick place to getaway that's not too far from Ithaca.

Kingsbury Woods Planned trail.Name: Kingsbury Woods Planned trail
Kingsbury Woods Planned trail.Description: The forest at Kingbury Woods protect over 6,000 feet along the upper reaches of Lick Brook in Ithaca.  Downstream from the preserve, Lick Brook carves a spectacular gorge on its way to the Cayuga Inlet below; here, however, the headwater streams course gently through old fields that are gradually reverting to hardwood forest.  In the spring, hikers can enjoy a 1.1 mile loop trail that skirts a vernal pool teeming with the activity of wood frogs, salamanders, insects and birds.  In the southern section of the woods stand several giant old oaks.  Dwarfing the surrounding, much younger hardwoods, these "wolf trees"Â once upon a time spread their impressive branches in an open field with broad views of the surround countryside.  In 2008, Sheela Kingsbury generously donated the 48 acre forest.  With the addition of this property, the Land Trust now has secured over 300 acres in the Lick Brook area, helping to protect Cayuga Inlet water quality and stem the tide of development on this lovely hillside.

parking lot: Small lot on Jersey Hill Rd across the road from trailhead

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: trail was really well marked! nothing special though, just a mile loop!
Kingsbury Woods is a nice quiet oasis in rural Tompkins County. The loop is short, but there are several scenic spots along the trail, such as the crossings of Lick Brook.
Quiet and remote, it's a perfect place for a (short) escape. Not much to see in terms of vistas, but it's a good place to hang out with some trees and moss and mud.

Lots of snow and icy in some spots but a great loop that wasn’t busy - just what I was looking for! The hardest part was the very beginning/end where there was a very short but steep incline for a few feet. The snow might be hiding some steps??

A nice loop but there were quite a bit of bugs constantly going for my face. My dog loved it though! Just a little short for the amount of energy she has. It would be great for anyone looking for an easy and non-crowded walk in the woods

Roy H. Park Preserve Blue trail.Name: Roy H. Park Preserve Blue trail
Roy H. Park Preserve Blue trail.Description: Just a short drive from Ithaca, this 241-acre preserve borders Yellow Barn and Hammond Hill State Forests and a Cornell Natural Area, making it an important connector in an array of nearly 8,000 acres of open space.  Protection of these lands adds another gem to the "Emerald Necklace,"Â the Land Trust's initiative to connect 50,000 acres of public land around Ithaca.   The preserve has more than 1.5 miles of hiking trails and a universally accessible boardwalk that offers visitors a path across Six-Mile Creek and a connection to more than 15 miles of multi-use trails on neighboring state land. In addition to the wetlands, the preserve features a mixed hardwood forest, hemlock woods, vernal pools, and an expansive beaver pond.  The vernal pools provide superb habitat for spotted salamanders and wood frogs.  On an early April day, listen for the ringing birdlike calls of spring peepers and the clackety-quacking of wood frogs heralding the coming of spring, and keep on the lookout for great blue herons. The Park Preserve is renowned among local birders for its splendid array of breeding birds.  In the forest, you may hear winter wren, hermit thrush, northern waterthrush, and Louisiana waterthrush; while in the field, listen for prairie warbler, eastern bluebird, tree swallow, eastern towhee, indigo bunting, and yellow-billed cuckoo.

parking lot: Small lot across from 975 Irish Settlement Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Pretty trail, but still lots of snow and ice present despite all the warm temps lately. Downhills are pretty treacherous- spikes would be helpful for another week or so.
Nicely packed snow trail.    Cold.
Nice trail.  Nice elevation.  Well trafficked, packed snow.
Perfectly adequate. Nothing spectacular, just pretty woods. Well-marked trail, just follow the red circles.

Started at the north parking lot. The trail was beautiful, and starts in the wetland area before moving up into the forested hill. Well-marked, but the leaves are covering the trail right now and made it a bit hard to follow. Wonderful bench/overlook at the beginning of the trail.
Short & Sweet
We hiked part of the trail from the north entrance. Boardwalk was really nice. Well marked and well maintained trails. Good hike, but the trail from the south entrance is so much better!
We actually started at the North parking lot of the Roy H Park Preserve, but didn’t start recording until we started the Hammond Hill Loop. Anyway, this is quite a pleasant walk.
This is a beautiful trail one way. Very short and sweet.
Good walk, not difficult with very nice woodlands. Had a Raven accompany us.

North entrance. Nice board walk to the woods. Great view of the wetlands which are critical to wildlife. I appreciated the benches. We saw dozens of bright orange salamanders and a tiny toad in the woods. Unfortunately the mosquitos and flies were out in full force. Having a hat helped, as did insect repellent. 2.4 miles was a short hike but I would go back late September, early October. I would probably extend my hike into Hammond State Forest. The North entrance is the first entrance on Irish Settlement rd coming from Rt 13. Just past Hammond Hill rd.

Important Note:  There are two Roy H. Park Preserve parking areas on Irish Settlement.  This review is for the one that starts at the South lot.  They are about 3/4 of a mile apart - The North lot starts with walk across a boardwalk through a marsh, and the South lot starts with a walk through some trees and small meadows.  The South lot trail is a beautiful short trail that I would say is an Easy loop of about 1.5 miles.  Mostly flat land with beautiful bird activity, especially in the mornings.  There are several side branches to the loop that head over to Sixmile Creek at various points, one that heads over to an open lean-to and baby gorge, the other goes down to a swimming hole on private property.  Generally they don't mind if you swim, just be respectful and don't leave trash.  A great hidden gem that is generally unused or extremely low traffic for being so close to Ithaca.
A lovely walk through wetlands and forest that will bring you to the Hammond Hill trail system.

Started at the north parking lot. The trail was beautiful, and starts in the wetland area before moving up into the forested hill. Well-marked, but the leaves are covering the trail right now and made it a bit hard to follow. Wonderful bench/overlook at the beginning of the trail.
Short & Sweet
We hiked part of the trail from the north entrance. Boardwalk was really nice. Well marked and well maintained trails. Good hike, but the trail from the south entrance is so much better!
We actually started at the North parking lot of the Roy H Park Preserve, but didn’t start recording until we started the Hammond Hill Loop. Anyway, this is quite a pleasant walk.
This is a beautiful trail one way. Very short and sweet.
Good walk, not difficult with very nice woodlands. Had a Raven accompany us.

North entrance. Nice board walk to the woods. Great view of the wetlands which are critical to wildlife. I appreciated the benches. We saw dozens of bright orange salamanders and a tiny toad in the woods. Unfortunately the mosquitos and flies were out in full force. Having a hat helped, as did insect repellent. 2.4 miles was a short hike but I would go back late September, early October. I would probably extend my hike into Hammond State Forest. The North entrance is the first entrance on Irish Settlement rd coming from Rt 13. Just past Hammond Hill rd.

Important Note:  There are two Roy H. Park Preserve parking areas on Irish Settlement.  This review is for the one that starts at the South lot.  They are about 3/4 of a mile apart - The North lot starts with walk across a boardwalk through a marsh, and the South lot starts with a walk through some trees and small meadows.  The South lot trail is a beautiful short trail that I would say is an Easy loop of about 1.5 miles.  Mostly flat land with beautiful bird activity, especially in the mornings.  There are several side branches to the loop that head over to Sixmile Creek at various points, one that heads over to an open lean-to and baby gorge, the other goes down to a swimming hole on private property.  Generally they don't mind if you swim, just be respectful and don't leave trash.  A great hidden gem that is generally unused or extremely low traffic for being so close to Ithaca.
A lovely walk through wetlands and forest that will bring you to the Hammond Hill trail system.

Roy H. Park Preserve Park path to Boardw.Name: Roy H. Park Preserve Park path to Boardwalk
Roy H. Park Preserve Park path to Boardw.Description: Just a short drive from Ithaca, this 241-acre preserve borders Yellow Barn and Hammond Hill State Forests and a Cornell Natural Area, making it an important connector in an array of nearly 8,000 acres of open space.  Protection of these lands adds another gem to the "Emerald Necklace,"Â the Land Trust's initiative to connect 50,000 acres of public land around Ithaca.   The preserve has more than 1.5 miles of hiking trails and a universally accessible boardwalk that offers visitors a path across Six-Mile Creek and a connection to more than 15 miles of multi-use trails on neighboring state land. In addition to the wetlands, the preserve features a mixed hardwood forest, hemlock woods, vernal pools, and an expansive beaver pond.  The vernal pools provide superb habitat for spotted salamanders and wood frogs.  On an early April day, listen for the ringing birdlike calls of spring peepers and the clackety-quacking of wood frogs heralding the coming of spring, and keep on the lookout for great blue herons. The Park Preserve is renowned among local birders for its splendid array of breeding birds.  In the forest, you may hear winter wren, hermit thrush, northern waterthrush, and Louisiana waterthrush; while in the field, listen for prairie warbler, eastern bluebird, tree swallow, eastern towhee, indigo bunting, and yellow-billed cuckoo.

parking lot: Large Parking lot across from 831 Irish Settlement Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Pretty trail, but still lots of snow and ice present despite all the warm temps lately. Downhills are pretty treacherous- spikes would be helpful for another week or so.
Nicely packed snow trail.    Cold.
Nice trail.  Nice elevation.  Well trafficked, packed snow.

Lindsay-Parsons Blue trail.Name: Lindsay-Parsons Blue trail
Lindsay-Parsons Blue trail.Description: The Lindsay-Parsons Biodiversity Preserve in the town of West Danby consists of 537 acres of forests, meadows, brushland, gorges, streams, kettle ponds and wetlands.  Several trails comprising a total of 3.6 miles are open year-round for hiking, skiing, and birding.  The diverse habitats found in the preserve are home to an equally diverse variety of flora and fauna.  Some rare species have been identified in the preserve and it provides an exceptional place for bird watching.  Additionally, the preserve's value for wildlife is enhanced by the fact that it borders Danby State Forest and sits along the Cayuga Inlet.   One of the Land Trust's and the Cornell Institute for Research in Chemical Ecology (CIRCE)'s goals for this preserve was to make it the world's first temperate-zone preserve for research in biodiversity and chemical ecology.  With this aim in mind, the scientists and students at Cornell have used the preserve to study the chemical interactions of organisms there.  Due to the size and diversity of this preserve, it is ideal for use by area colleges and schools for different educational purposes.  It also provides an excellent place for quiet contemplation.

parking lot: Parking is 1/2 mile south of Sylvan Drive, on the east side of the road. Entrance to the parking lot is at the top of a hill, opposite a house and barn.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Beautiful and nice trail. Some steeper inclines, declines and uneven tail but not overly challenging. The trail is well marked and maintained. Benches throughout the trails to view the beautiful rolling hills and fields.  Trail is a little different than what is marked on the All trails app- which actually made for a better experience. Plenty of parking. It wasn't a surprise that we had a few ticks, so remember to take extra precautions.
Great hike.  Rolling hills.  Glad I wore yak-tracks to make it up and down the packed snow and icy hills.
Explored more of the yellow and orange trails beyond this one! Some parts icy but manageable and beautiful frozen bog!
Beautiful in the winter!  Can’t wait to come back and do all of it, without my 8 year old!
Nice, quiet, scenic trail system.
Lots of ticks! Otherwise a well-maintained, easy trail.
One of my favorite places to go! The trails loop around to give you an option of taking a nice long walk or a short trek. The wetlands are beautiful.

This hiking area is one of the best hidden gems in Ithaca for a jaunt, really in any season.  Lots of short up and down on small rolling hills that helps it just feel further out than it is.  There are lots of possibilities for where to walk that are detailed better here https://ithacatrails.org/map.  There is also a map at the parking area that shows you these sub-trails.  Explore them all during different seasons, and if you get a chance, take a full-moon hike in the winter.  You will not regret waking up and bundling up to enjoy the quiet.

We hiked this set of trails with our dog down to the lake to see the beaver pond and dam. Then over to the railroad tracks and back. Wide trails, easy pace, lovely meadows and terrain. Muddy is spots so be prepared. Next time we will get up onto the ridge and see the bowl and forest. Great little spot

This is a cool little hike that is a nice stop and dash. Parking right off of Route 34 and nice wide well groomed trails. It's a nice view once you reach the water area and all in all worth the hike. A must do if you are in the area. A quick easy 3 miles
Easy and relatively flat trail...    Well maintained!
An easy loop, well-maintained and pretty! It's a nice hike to take children along with, because there aren't much elevation and the ponds and geese, blue heron etc. will please them!

Stevenson Forest Preserve Blue trail.Name: Stevenson Forest Preserve Blue trail
Stevenson Forest Preserve Blue trail.Description: Twenty-five acres of the Stevenson Forest Preserve had been owned by the Stevenson family of Enfield since after the Revolutionary War.  In 1995, this fine old forest became the first parcel of the preserve that would eventually grow to 83 acres.  Today, visitors can enjoy a 1.2 mile hiking trail that ends in an impressive view of the Enfield Valley.  The history of the Stevenson Preserve is visible not only as paragraphs of a deed, but also in the grandeur of its trees.  The original 25-acre parcel is a patch of undisturbed forest that is quickly becoming a rarity.  A number of the trees that create a dense canopy had their start at least 150 years ago.  Unlike their counterparts in most regions of the northeast, these trees have only a faint memory of the mass felling that occurred in the rush to turn forest to farmland.  The preserve has several vernal ponds that support a variety of aquatic life.  In early spring, it may be possible to witness the migration of spotted salamanders from their winter hideaways to the shallow water. Trail visitors will notice the white-blazed Finger Lakes Trail/North Country National Scenic Trail along the way.

parking lot: Pull-off on north side of Trumbulls Corners Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: The Stevenson preserve main loop is an easy half mile loop around pine groves.  It features 'vernal pools', and leads to another trail that has a view at the end.  Park at the pull out from Trumbull Corners Road.  This preserve is part of the finer lakes land trust.  https://www.fllt.org/preserves/stevenson-forest-preserve/

Genung Trail.Name: Genung Trail
Genung Trail.Description: Dedicated in July 2007, the Genung Nature Preserve stretches along a mile of Fall Creek as it takes a great bend on its way to Cayuga Lake. The preserve is open for people to explore an easy trail through various habitats and enjoy a quiet respite from the noise of everyday life. Â The trail wanders through shrubby areas, a grove of Musclewood (or Ironwood) trees along the bank of Fall Creek, some of the wildest Hawthorn trees you will ever see, then larger hardwood trees such as swamp White Oak, Red Oak, Sugar Maple, Basswood and Shagbark Hickory. This trail is owned by the Village of Freeville.

parking lot: Small pull-off on the west side of Route 38, just north of the 4 corners of 366 and 38

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Unblazed trail, used the snowshoes was awesome.  Main trail, however is closed.

I walk the left hand trail (from the parking lot, into the village of Freeville) every day, to and from work.  As of October 2020, the main trail (right hand trail, from parking lot) remains "closed until further notice", and last I knew the bridges were in pretty sad shape, so there may be maintenance being done. However the trail i take every day is easy, yet just challenging enough (a few small stumps coming up out of the ground on the trail, some overhanging branches, slippery-when-wet bridges, many twists and turns, etc.), but the main thing to look out for is the one bridge that's out. There is a small gap to clear, so don't fall in! I see a bunch of different birds and animals every day.  I've seen deer, gray squirrels, red squirrels, garter snakes, blue jays, woodpeckers, blue heron, and green heron just to name a few. Very peaceful trail with nice views of the creek on one side and the forest on the other. I would not recommend it for running, it's way too narrow and slippery in spots. Definitely not for bicycles or strollers or wheelchairs. Good trail overall, about a 10 minute hike one way.
Trail was okay. Looks like they did a little clean-up. Bridges are rickety but you are warned with signs.
OK trail. Nice views of the river, but no access spots to get down near the water. The loop is really overgrown and difficult to follow. Bring your bug spray!

The start of this loop is somewhat difficult to find. You have to take the trail on the right side of the parking lot and turn right at the first intersection. Left will take you down a trail to the village of Freeville. The trail is peaceful but very overgrown, so it needs maintenance. There's nothing special about it but it's worth a visit if you're nearby.
Narrow trail that follows a creek in freeville. Easy walk but it is narrow!

Cayuga Trail.Name: Cayuga Trail
Cayuga Trail.Description: Visitors can explore Cornell Botanic Gardens Beebe Lake Natural Area on the one-mile loop trail around this man-made lake in the heart of Cornell campus. The scenic trail passes through mature and old-growth forests, over the historic Sackett Bridge, and past many lake views and stone seating areas that include picturesque views across the lake and the falls over Beebe Dam into Fall Creek Gorge from the Triphammer Footbridge.  These trails are also a favorite for joggers, hikers or a simple stroll. A shorter loop trail from Sackett's Bridge leads to a picnic area overlooking a waterfall tucked away in Hemlock Gorge.  While hiking the trail, visitors may take an interpretive guided tour using your smart phone by downloading "Pocketsights Tour Guide" from the App Store or Google Play Store. Trails here also connect with the Cayuga Trail, and trails within the Botanic Garden area, the Mundy Wildflower Garden, Cornell Campus, and additional, adjoining natural areas.

parking lot: 1 Plantations Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Thankful for the still frozen ground that made this trail less of a mud bath. With the warming temps, I'll wait for it to dry up before attempting again. Otherwise, this trail is a favorite! Great for running, varied terrain, great scenery. Take the time to walk through the arboretum.
Muddy in spots but nice scenery

Late March hike. Very muddy in parts. Clocked more than 10 miles. Nice variety of terrain, including farmland, riverfront trails, and Ithaca outskirts. Did it with a hiking newcomer who found it challenging but doable.
I thought the trail was very neat, and the cliffs were spectacular!! .
Very muddy and pretty challenging terrain for those with low mobility, but beautiful and fun!
Relaxing long hike.  Great mix of farm, fields, gorge, and forest.  It can be hard to follow the markers at time.  Keep your eyes on the trees!

parked at monkey run and started clockwise only to lose the trail as it cuts across farmland less than a mile in. circled the entire farm then retraced counterclockwise, turned 9 miles into 12. nice hike!
amazing 8 miles...be aware around mile 1.5 you have to cross the river in the road ....but
not well marked need more maintenance other wise nice.

This trail is lots of fun if you’re looking for a longer day hike! Easy side of moderate, the trail is mostly flat. However, you will need to look out for the blazes and refer to the map to follow the trail which goes in and out of the forest, crossing streets and large, open fields. Be prepared! The trail was overgrown with foliage but nothing that would obscure your passage. Bugs are out, but that is typical for this time of year. The trail intersects a river, offering beautiful views and an opportunity to play in the water.
Overall, a very nice trail. Lower end of 'Moderate' in terms of effort. First mile or so not great, but give it time, it gets much better after the highway!

Lovely hike. Muddy as all get-out but if you’re a fan of messy spring time you’re in for a treat. I started at the Monkey Run parking area and it made a perfect 9 miler.  Agree with others that there are a few “wtf” moments but when in doubt, follow the peach trail markers and you can do no wrong.

You no longer have to walk on the Ithaca-Dryden Road (Rt 366).  The official trail now cuts into the woods on the left immediately after crossing southwest across the historic 1886 Freese Road bridge.

No clear markers or signs to trail from the coordinates provided on here. Leads to an apartment complex which also has no signage for trail or anything of the sort. As some others have suggested in comments prior, not a clear starting point in sight. Couldn't find parking or trail. Drove around for a bit, still nothing. Ended up going to another spot about 20 minutes away.

This was a great hike, although I should have studied the map a little bit more before I got there. If you want to do the entire 9.3 mile loop, (park by going down the dirt road next to the apartments) and simply follow the orange blaze. This is a very, very well marked trail. With some just beautiful views! Took me 4 hours.  Also, I only saw one other person on the trail. Oh, and only one kinda muddy spot.  I brought my dog. He loved it too
Very long, tranquil, desolate trail. I didn’t run into a single person. Trail runs along a river for quite some time and has some nice overlooks.
Not a ton to look at. Easy to follow for the most part.

This is a beautiful and fairly easy hike. We did it on a 45 degree January day, so there were sections that were very muddy—which made steeper sections a bit harder than they would be normally.  Two big things to be aware of for this hike: First, there are lots of places to park along the trail, however, the spot the directions button takes you to is an apartment complex that requires parking tags to park... two good spots to park include: at the bottom of Monkey Run road (a dead end that has parking at the end) and the section of the hike that crosses a one way bridge (I’m not sure the road name). But, my recommendation is to figure out parking first! We parked at Cornell on Caldwell Drive and Forest Home—a third good option.   Second, there are a number of sections of this hike that are very poorly marked, and these spots are often at weird intersections or spots that are confusing—so be aware of this. What makes it more confusing is that from the Cornell end, the Cayuga trail isn’t marked Cayuga consistently—and there are a number of smaller Cornell trails that are marked. We ended up on other trails in this section, and as a result, ended up doing 11 miles total.   I suspect others also got lost or sidetracked on the other trails, too—if you open up the record button above, you can see very few of those recording are similar or actually line up w the official Cayuga loop.

Admittedly, it was a tough day to go out.  Cold and rainy.  Maybe that might affect this review, but I was more disappointed with the long stretch of old road/railroad bed that comprised a pretty big part of this trek.   I will come back and try the rest of the trail based on other reviews.

Pretty muddy this time of year, there were times it felt more like a swim than a hike!  But that just added to the adventure of this otherwise moderate hike.  Nice view of Fall Creek at some spots.  Avoid the edge when up on the ridge--saw a tree fall off the hillside which illustrates the erosion that is continually happening there.

This is a great trail! to piggyback on what others have said the variety of ecosystems and elevations are just amazing I like that it is lightly used as well and I'll be bringing my Hiking Club here every once in a while it's a great addition to our regular rotation of hikes!

I love this path, perhaps for nostalgia sake, but it really is beautiful and exemplifies why Ithaca is GORGEous! I would run this track in the evenings and reminded how beautiful the world can be! Wonderful in the winter too with all the snow but less friendly for running!
Love it!

A friend and I just hiked this trail start to end and back to start, during late March. The campus section is a patchwork of natural areas and civilization, but it gets a bit more wild as it goes. It passes through a variety of different ecosystems/topographies, and there are a couple spots with pretty nice views. There are also some points where the routing of the trail feels a bit arbitrary and unnecessary. The trail is pretty well blazed in most spots, but having the map and/or directions can be a helpful backup. There are no bathrooms or places to get water (except for the Plantations Visitors Center).
One of my favorite trails!

This is a very beautiful hike. There are some steep areas but not many. The views of the gorge are stunning, especially in fall. The markings on the trees could be a bit better though. It might be easy to lose track for inexperienced hikers.
Nice trail well maintained with some beautiful gorge views.  It is not a very difficult trail; only a few short sections might be a little steep!
Nice trail not too difficult. Beautiful scenery.
I love hiking in the Ithaca area, nice trails, scenery, and all around good time.

Edwards Lake Cliiffs Trail - Pocket Fall.Name: Edwards Lake Cliiffs Trail - Pocket Falls
Edwards Lake Cliiffs Trail - Pocket Fall.Description: Within the 84-acre Cornell Botanic Gardens Edwards Lake Cliffs Natural Area, trails bring visitors to scenic views of Cayuga Lake, a gorge and waterfall.  The Lake View Trail leads to an expansive view of the lake atop cliffs of Tully Limestone. These lake cliffs and the specialized plant communities they support are found only in a few places in the region. The Pocket Falls Trail leads to a view of a 35-foot waterfall from the forested rim of Shurger Glen.  The main Loop Trail takes visitors through younger forest, shrub thickets and meadows.

street: 95 Teeter Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
This trail is closed during firearm deer hunting season.
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Cornell appears to have closed this trail. No trespassing signs posted. Decent view of the lake from the padlocked fence...
wow it's a mudder here.  watch for periodic winter closures during hunting season.
Best overlook of Cayuga Lake is on this trail. Generally pretty unknown and jaw-dropping.
Wonderful trail. Natural beauty. Some steep spots and some flats.
little muddy but beautiful forest, leaves and sights of cayuga lake were awesome.

Nice variety of terrain from fairly open fields to forest with ravines. Sadly the trail ends at the creek bed ABOVE the big waterfall.   I found a way to the creek bed by crossing it and going up then down quite steep hills. I re-started recording once in the creek bed and after crossing back over found a herd path that was FAR easier than what I did. See the waypoint on my recording and my photo with where to look for it. It’s as you are going downhill towards the creek. Good luck!
Great views. Not crowded at all. Overall the trail system is pretty short, maybe 2 miles? The biggest issue is it’s pretty much all invasives. Tons of privet.
Beautiful day and a beautiful trail
Exceedingly pleasant.  This is a very well-marked, well-maintained trail just minutes from Ithaca. Not one you do to train for climbing mountains, just one for being outdoors in gorgeous scenery.
Fantastic lake views. Great creek with gorge and waterfalls. Needs more shade.
Great Lake view and fun creekbed to explore. Needs more shade in spots!

Beautiful views of Cayuga Lake! Nice walk in woods and meadows. The waterfall was pretty dry in Aug 20 and we had trouble getting any good views of it. There is a trail that goes to the base of the waterfall but it appeared to be closed. Still a fun hike!
Wonderful family hike including our dog! Although the waterfall was a trickle, the canyon was beautiful!

Not the most exciting trail, but a nice forest with plenty of snails. You can see the top of the waterfall, but hard to get a good view of the drop from the trail. Decent views of the lake towards the bottom. Not at all crowded on a Friday afternoon. 75% shady.

This one has it all in under 2 mile loop: fields, woods, rivers, a waterfall, cliffs, lake views. Highly recommend going a bit out of the way if you're down in Ithaca looking for something a little different. We went on a weekday and it was empty.
grass on trail paths are overgrown but overall an easy trail with beautiful views of the lake!

lovely walk! Be wary of poison ivy in wooded areas just off the path, when stepping off to allow others to pass. We saw no one around the waterfall and 3 groups near the lake, all wearing masks and being mindful of social distancing. No bugs today and no mud. Tennis shoes are fine for this trail.
The trail of snails! Be careful walking this trail with so many adorable snails that like to be on the trail ground. Beautiful spots to sit and enjoy.

Found this spot after doing the Emilie Jones trail up the road and glad we did. My son (4) and I took the trail to the waterfall then walked upstream in the creek. Great spot to relax and my son loved playing in and around the water. Was an easy walk and will definitely go again.
we only did a portion of this trail but it was fun. we named it "snail trail" because there's snails in the trees.
loved this loop..walk to to see the views of the lake. then get into the woods and hike down to a BEAUTIFUL waterfall..there are a couple small ones when you walk up the creek.

This is a nice accessible nature preserve from the Lansing communities. There is a scenic overlook of Cayuga Lake and a tall waterfall. The trails were somewhat muddy, especially the yellow-blazed trail, and there were some bugs as well. I would recommend this for a quick walk to see the lake and the waterfall but there is not much scenery otherwise.

Edwards Lake Cliiffs Trail - Loop.Name: Edwards Lake Cliiffs Trail - Loop

The Pocket Falls Trail leads to a view of a 35-foot waterfall from the forested rim of Shurger Glen.  The main Loop Trail takes visitors through younger forest, shrub thickets and meadows.

street: 95 Teeter Rd.

This trail is closed during firearm deer hunting season.
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

wow it's a mudder here.  watch for periodic winter closures during hunting season.
Best overlook of Cayuga Lake is on this trail. Generally pretty unknown and jaw-dropping.
Wonderful trail. Natural beauty. Some steep spots and some flats.
little muddy but beautiful forest, leaves and sights of cayuga lake were awesome.

Fantastic lake views. Great creek with gorge and waterfalls. Needs more shade.
Great Lake view and fun creekbed to explore. Needs more shade in spots!

Beautiful views of Cayuga Lake! Nice walk in woods and meadows. The waterfall was pretty dry in Aug 20 and we had trouble getting any good views of it. There is a trail that goes to the base of the waterfall but it appeared to be closed. Still a fun hike!
Wonderful family hike including our dog! Although the waterfall was a trickle, the canyon was beautiful!

Not the most exciting trail, but a nice forest with plenty of snails. You can see the top of the waterfall, but hard to get a good view of the drop from the trail. Decent views of the lake towards the bottom. Not at all crowded on a Friday afternoon. 75% shady.

This one has it all in under 2 mile loop: fields, woods, rivers, a waterfall, cliffs, lake views. Highly recommend going a bit out of the way if you're down in Ithaca looking for something a little different. We went on a weekday and it was empty.
grass on trail paths are overgrown but overall an easy trail with beautiful views of the lake!

lovely walk! Be wary of poison ivy in wooded areas just off the path, when stepping off to allow others to pass. We saw no one around the waterfall and 3 groups near the lake, all wearing masks and being mindful of social distancing. No bugs today and no mud. Tennis shoes are fine for this trail.
The trail of snails! Be careful walking this trail with so many adorable snails that like to be on the trail ground. Beautiful spots to sit and enjoy.

Found this spot after doing the Emilie Jones trail up the road and glad we did. My son (4) and I took the trail to the waterfall then walked upstream in the creek. Great spot to relax and my son loved playing in and around the water. Was an easy walk and will definitely go again.
we only did a portion of this trail but it was fun. we named it "snail trail" because there's snails in the trees.
loved this loop..walk to to see the views of the lake. then get into the woods and hike down to a BEAUTIFUL waterfall..there are a couple small ones when you walk up the creek.

The trails were somewhat muddy, especially the yellow-blazed trail, and there were some bugs as well. I would recommend this for a quick walk to see the lake and the waterfall but there is not much scenery otherwise.

we only did a portion of this trail but it was fun. we named it "snail trail" because there's snails in the trees.
loved this loop..walk to to see the views of the lake. then get into the woods and hike down to a BEAUTIFUL waterfall..there are a couple small ones when you walk up the creek.

Finger Lakes Trail - Lick Brook.Name: Finger Lakes Trail - Lick Brook
Finger Lakes Trail - Lick Brook.Description: Cornell Botanic Gardens Lick Brook Gorge, which abuts the Finger Lakes Land Trust's Sweedler Preserve, is accessed by a section of the Finger Lakes Trail.  The preserve protects a deep gorge, cut by a stream on the eastern slope of the Cayuga Inlet valley. Breathtaking views of the gorge and its multiple waterfalls can be enjoyed along the trail.                                                                Please be aware of signs for trail closures during hunting season.

parking lot: 1027 Elmira Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
This trail is closed during firearm deer hunting season.
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: The trail was really great we got a little bit lost at first but then we found our way and it was very beautiful lots of waterfalls and snakes￼

On a stunner of a Spring day, we did this hike with our 8 year old and cocker spaniel - we all loved it.  The climb is a healthy cardio workout, the views are beautiful and the creek bed had us hunting for salamanders & fossils.

Beautiful! Very few people and lots of waterfalls to discover at every turn. Trails were clearly blazed and well maintained, and crossing the railroad bridge (right after a train did) was a unique treat.

My husband and I hiked this trail on 3-27-21 with our dog.  This is our first time doing this hike, and we really loved it.  We have hiked Buttermilk and Robert H. Treman several times and didn't even realize this hike existed until we found it here on AllTrails. We were very pleasantly surprised.  The waterfalls were beautiful, and I am not sure where the 3 waterfalls came from because it was more like double that number.  We talked to another hiker who told us that sometimes the brook is dried up, so it probably is not the same at other times of the year.  There was plenty of water flowing when we hiked though.  There was also a beautiful view overlooking the surrounding areas at one spot through the trees.   The hike was not what we consider difficult, but the climb up the hill is very steep for about 3/4 of a mile.  It was a good cardio workout, and you should be in decent shape to do it.  The trail was not rocky and we came across very little mud, no overgrowth, no bugs, and not crowded at all.  The railroad bridge in the very beginning was a new thing for us and realize the tracks are live.   Otherwise, you can traverse the water underneath, which was quite high when we were there.  We would definitely do this hike again.  it took us about 2 hours and 20 minutes to do this hike, but realize that we take our time to take pictures and enjoy the surroundings. The dog was fine and thoroughly enjoyed it too.  We would definitely do this hike again, it was a great afternoon, and more like "real hiking" to us compared to Buttermilk and Robert Treman. --Jennifer

A tad muddy but that’s expected this time of year. The main trail was a bit hard to find- don’t go up the side with the rock marker. Make sure you cross the river before you start going up. The railroad bridge at the beginning/end was my favorite part!
Icy. Micro spikes highly recommended

This was a beautiful trail with lots of awesome waterfalls along the way. We hiked in the winter, so there was a lot of ice over the trail so the steeper parts got a bit tricky. (Definitely would recommend spikes/ice shoes) I recommend hiking down the blue trail until you get to Lick Brook and then taking the white up. (The white is a big loop that takes you to the same place it’s just a bit longer) A great trail overall! Not too many people and gorges views ;)

An absolute beauty in Winter! It was like hiking through Narnia. I highly recommend the white trail for an easy stroll through beautiful waterfalls or the blue trail for a steeper challenge! Excited to come back here in other seasons!
Closed so hunters can go murder animals.

A little icy for some parts, but do-able without yaktrax. Lightly trafficked on a Friday afternoon and a good, strenuous hike on the uphill. Beautiful views of the partially frozen waterfall! A wonderful new year's escape.
I would rate this as difficult. Steep climb at the start and fairly slippery parts throughout. Totally worth it for the beautiful views. Not too crowded on a Friday winter afternoon.
Parked at sandbank and town line road to hike from top.  Lovely trail along the brook.
Careful of the hunters

moderately trafficked trail, watch for closures during hunting season. pretty views on the blue trail and around the loop up at the top.  can get muddy, also the leaves can make it slippery in the the fall.
Nice, quiet trail.  it was very dry when we were there, but it looked like there would be a beautiful fall there.
Good trail. Good ascent. Multiple paths, so there are options to choose from, and the way there is different than the way back.
Decent hike with some challenging spots.

Overall it was very marked. It was a beautiful day.  We followed the white trail markings going up (and up and up) and the blue markings coming down. We met up with the white markings to go back to the parking off of Elmira Road.

The trail is well maintained,  but you do need to know that it is not flat!  There are a lot of roots, too. I even tripped, landed face down,  but not injured. We started at the bottom and that is the only part of the trail that is sunny.  Otherwise very shady and quite comfortable on a September day.   You can choose the blue trail which is much steeper or the white trail, but longer, that goes between two ravines. Quite beautiful!

Great trail with a challenging ascent. Docked a star because you can hear traffic for most of the hike, and the 'How to get there' instructions currently route toward the middle of the route instead of directing people to the parking lot off of Elmira Road that would allow a solid out and back.
Extreme elevation! be prepared! also next to a really nice gorge!

The waterfalls unfortunately are not flowing heavily so they are more of trickles but the gorge is still beautiful.  This trail is close to a major highway so you don’t really get the complete quietness that some seek with hiking but still a great hike!!
Very nice, well-maintained and marked. could go onto buttermilk falls via the FLT system if one wanted. Not too busy and nice waterfalls which would be amazing in the spring.
Wonderful! Just wish the trail led to a better lookout for the view.  Great workout.

Only went for a quick 1.5 mile jaunt.  White trail takes you up to (and under) a trestle.  After that it’s all canopy so it was a bit dark to finish this today.  The thunderstorm confirmed I should get out of there.    Will definitely be back!
Always a good hike. Inclines are steep and can quickly become tiresome so pick a cool breezy day to tackle this one
Quiet hike- not crowded on a Saturday afternoon. The gorges were all dried up though- no waterfalls.
Brook was dry, cicadas were noisy, super hot and humid, but still one of the best places to spend an hour near Ithaca.

Great trail but the water was treated with chemicals. There was a flowing stream and no way to pass other then the train tracks. Great hike nothing to see. Great hike to put some mileage. Nothing to see other then a stream with no water. It’s pretty much dried out. Muddy at times due to the rain
Well marked & well maintained trail. Steady moderate climb & beautiful gorge views. Light traffic on a hot Friday afternoon. Much of the gorge is currently dry but trail is still lovely.

On July 5 there were no waterfalls.  Just a trickle of water in the creek.  Still if you walk the creek bed, it's much more beautiful than staying on the trail all the time. Starting out, it's flat.  Within 1/2 mile it's all uphill.
Trail was nice. Local swimming hole hike. No water due to no rain. Very nice, good cardio.

This was a beautiful hike! Took the blue trail down, walked to Buttermilk Falls and came back up the white trail. Views of the gorge were just stunning. Trails were well marked. About 5 miles round trip. Real talk: this is a steep descent and equally steep ascent. It is not an easy climb back up, even for those in good health. Be aware.
good for trail running and hiking  core muscle workout.very quite and feel 100% natural more than regular trail.
Good trail  Nice trail for training  Beautiful day overall  Great hike

Great trail. I went about 6:30am, done at 7:30 am, and there was no one there; loved it! Very easy trail for dogs, even the incline by the falls. There was no running water, but beautiful nonetheless. I parked at the top of the red trail and looped around to white, then blue. That made the incline the last leg of the journey. I suppose you could park below on the white trail and make the incline the first thing you do...(?).

Beautiful, interesting trail. Was completely uncrowded at start but saw quite a few people on return-but it was a nice Saturday afternoon.  Gorgeous wildflower fields at start then some steep sections by the gorge. Water level was low so falls were a bit light, but a wonderful hike.
Really nice views. Good choice on a cool day.

Beautiful trail through the woods with some waterfalls! This trail does have steep inclines, unlike many Ithacan trails that are flat. I suggest making sure your water is with you, especially if it is hot and you normally get away with not bringing it. The trail mapped out above is the WHITE marked trail. There is also a red and blue marked trail.  It also gets a little buggy when you are walking through the field!
Great secluded trail. Not a ton of views considering the incline of the blue blaze trail.

Really cute trail! Just a few tips if heading from route 34 trail head...when heading into the trail, bear to the right, you’ll come to a train bridge. You have to walk over the bridge. As soon as you’re over the bridge hang a right and you’ll start up on the white trail. The blue trail comes off of the white trail after the first waterfall. Take this up, it’s steep but so much better views. The white trail on the way back down is beautiful too, just can’t see the water falls.  Phlox were in bloom, beautiful views, not a ton of people even on a fairly nice Sunday afternoon. Enjoy this hidden gem :)
Delightful!!! Beautiful!!! Wish we lived close to come all the time!
Great trail. If you enter from route 34 trailhead be sure to walk across or under the railroad bridge to follow the White path. It can be deceptive once you hit the water.
3 great waterfalls for such a quick hike
Absolutely beautiful... pretty steep going up but some switchbacks make it easier.
A very nice nature preserve in the finger lakes trail system. It offers trails just as nice as the major gorges of Ithaca, if not nicer. Even the day after a rainstorm, none of the trails were muddy.
Amazing hike-Great views and beautiful waterfalls! Trails are nicely maintained- steep section on the blue trail but easy switchback trails and stairs. Highly recommend!

Buttermilk falls parking lots, both of them, were full despite the orange cones blocking off every other spot due to the quarantine (people moved them and parked in the spots anyway). So we headed to Lick Brook which was also busier than normal but not crazy busy. Rob a found a nurse rock & a lady bug rock. #ithacarocks

Nice trail. Recommend follow the blue path up for a steep ascent and view of the largest Lick Brook falls. Then follow the white path down which winds through a parallel peaceful gorge for a more gradual decent.
great trail but a bit slippery with the mud. also came out with several ticks!
Icy and muddy! I had to go off trail a few times to get a grip, but it was worth it.

I went here yesterday. Parked on Town Line Road, as GPS led me to a bridge on the main road with no parking area and I had to find another way to the trails. Hiked downhill with minimal sliding. All of the waterfalls were flowing with so much water! The hike back up wasn’t too bad, definitely had a lot of water and was sweating despite the 30 degree weather. There was no ice but a lot of leaves on the ground. Beautiful views!
Nice home with several small water falls. Trails marked well. Great day.

After living in the area most of our lives we finally got around to hiking this trail. It was quiet, well marked and quite enjoyable. I can see that in wetter weather it would have issues. Definitely want to switch to the blue trail if there is much water. There may have only been a trickle running through the gorges but it was still beautiful. Definitely a moderate trail. Looking forward to seeing it in the spring.
This was more than Moderate...... And it was HOT... Tracey didn’t realize it would be so Woodsy in the Woods...

The Allltrails app will put you into the parking off of Danby Road. Note; Robert Treman Park is just down the road to the left.   The trail is just to the right of the parking area and it not marked until further into the woods. Stay to the right, then cross the bridge, then another right after the bridge you will go few hundred feet and then a left. Cross the dry creek bed f you want to view the falls. It is uphill most of the way and has a few switchbacks making the assent easier.   We followed the blue blazes most of the hike. The falls were quite dry today but scenic still with the trickle of water that was dancing down the rocks. We would like to visit the falls when there is more water flowing.
great hike. nice and quiet.

Hiked this gorge several time a month every month .  It is a beautiful hike in all seasons.  I have photos and videos for all seasons.  The recently added steps make the blue trail easier but it still is a workout.   Depending on the season and the rainfall the falls can be gushing or trickling.  Snow and ice in the winter provide a spectacular setting.  Start the hike at the Town Line Road parking area.

We started at the bottom trail head but there is a trail head above the falls. Very pretty trail. It is not well marked. The blue trail is steep but goes along with the white trail which is an alternate but goes to the same place.  The waterfalls are lovely. it is a small creek so dont expect a lot of water.
Motherlode of falls. All were flowing good. Trail crew from the Adirondack Mtn Club was on the trail building steps.
Nice short trail if you are in the area. I wouldn't go out of my way for this hike though. We have stopped 2x while we were in the area. Both times there was only a small trickle.

“Gorges” waterfalls and a nice solid hike. Brought the pup on this hike this afternoon. Falls are very strong right now and caused us to have to make our own paths around to stay on the trails..some we just couldn’t manage to cross (the upper part of the loop). We also ended up using the railroad track/white bridge to get around the steam. Ground was soft and muddy a good amount of the time and we ticks are out. We found 10-12 on him after the hike.
great place to hike but it is closed for hunting from 1/12/19-1/31/19
Three large falls and many smaller falls. When the water is flowing through the gorge it is spectacular!
Did the trail today  hot and muggy for October  Leaves are changing.  The falls had plenty water flowing and great hike  was steep in the middle section   Popular trail being near Ithaca

This was a long steady hike up hill we took a lot of short brakes on the blue trail, and coming back down we took the white trail seemed a bit easier. My knees were starting to really feel it so when we hit steep spots I would walk backwards and that saved me, a beautiful hike and we’ll try it again when there’s more water for the falls and many cascades. It will be a 5 star hike for sure. P.S. theirs a water crossing under the train trestle, and possibly more if theres wet weather we took our shoes off to cross.
Dry season / lots of bugs / decent elevation and quiet
Not very busy. Very steep in a few places. Falls were a bit dried up but still pretty.
Great hike pretty steep in some areas
Great Hike, Beautiful Scenery
Beautiful trail
Beautiful falls, all the hikers we encountered were very friendly!

A less frequently used trail and for good reason. The elevation gain up the hill from the waterfall is substantial and the grade very steep. It is a workout even for those in good condition, but well rewarded. Once at the top it becomes a trail of gentle ups and downs always close to the brook, and almost entirely in the woods. If you go to the Blue trail it takes you back on the other side of water before rejoining the main trail. Plan on an hour and a half and when descending I suggest taking the white trail to the right. It brings you to waterfall but meanders through the woods and across many streams and a lovely ridge view.
I’ve been here many years ago and have forgotten how beautiful it is. Great hike to get the heart pumping.

Tougher/steeper hike than expected. Many of the falls were dried up, but the lowest point had a nice area of water to romp around in. Good exercise on the ascent back up. Have some nice ledges to sit on looking down into the gorges.
Relatively short trail with great views. Dog-friendly. A few nice ledges overlooking the water to rest on if necessary. Take the time to stop and play in the water at the bottom!
nice hike down I started at the top but going back up wasn't so nice...lol all in all it was worth it
Once you find it, it's a nice hidden gem! Fairly steep incline on the way out but shady enough that it's not too bad. Many picturesque spots to stop and just appreciate if you need little breaks.
Some steep sections but many incredible views!
Nice trail though no water this time. Part is closed for hunting season but can easily be rerouted. Going to come back and check out in the winter I bet it is awesome all 4 seasons.
Beautiful humid September day.  Didn't expect to sweat quite so much! Gorgeous hike  and view even though water was so low this year.
great rugged trail
Good hike; surprised by how much I was sweating in the
Excellent undisturbed hike - no man made barriers. Numerous waterfalls (two large falls) with a lot of character. there is quite an elevation change, mostly the bottom third of the trail.
view are not great. nice but there are pleanty of nicer hikes around
Amazing! My new favorite spot. It is VERY steep though, I'm 23 and athletic and I would say it's more like a cliff than steep hill haha.
Strenuous but amazing hike. A  great place to observe New York and its diverse ecosystems.
Nice trail!  Lovely falls!

I really enjoy this trail for a quick getaway to the woods. Its a great strenuous walk that I've taken several times & I never get bored with it. Great place for peace & quiet as I rarely run into anyone else there.
Well marked trails with beautiful views!  Contains a serious climb back out!  The views of the falls are well worth the hike.

The best part of Havana glen is unseen most of the glen is above the big falls just don't get caught up their and if one does go up their one must be extremely carful ..... If you explore know it is posted now because someone fell of a cliff they are very high CAUTION

Cascadilla Gorge Trail - North Rim.Name: Cascadilla Gorge Trail - North Rim
Cascadilla Gorge Trail - North Rim.Description: The iconic Cornell Botanic Gardens Cascadilla Gorge Trail connects downtown Ithaca with the Cornell Campus among one of the most picturesque gorges in the Finger Lakes Region and was voted Ithaca's favorite gorge.  Ascending over 400 feet, this historic set of stone trails and staircases was originally constructed in the late 1920's, and takes visitors through the gorge formed from ancient bedrock and past six waterfalls.  At a leisurely pace, this 1/3-mile section of the trail takes less than an hour from the Treman Triangle Park in downtown to the upper entrance by the College Avenue Stone Arch Bridge. In Collegetown, the trail crosses College Avenue and the Goldwin Smith Walk continues to follow Cascadilla Creek for another half mile through a flat, wooded area that leads to two footbridges over scenic waterfalls. The lower gorge from Linn St to College Ave is closed during the winter months, but the gorge above College Ave is open year round.

parking lot: Hoy Rd. Parking Garage

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Very nice! Steep steps but quick
Meh. Just do the lower unless you want a short nature walk w college students.
Well maintained. Beautiful gem in the middle of Ithaca.
Pleasant walking trail around Cornell.
Hit this on out way out of town for a little extra something. Fun, beautiful. Cornell students are lucky!
Quick loop to add onto Cascadilla trails - fun add on! Well maintained
This was my favorite waterfall hike in Ithaca. Lots of stars but there are so many beautiful things to see that there are plenty of places to stop and take in the sights. I cant wait to come back.
Nice shady walk through the trees & along the creek.  Pretty area.
Eh. It was ok. The full trail was closed.

This is an extension of the Lower Cascadilla Gorge Trail from Downtown Ithaca. It is a nice, wooded gorge with a few waterfalls. The loop is short but scenic. I recommend doing this only as a continuation of the Lower Gorge Trail, as it is not worth a separate visit.
