Ellis Hollow Wetlands Trail.Name: Ellis Hollow Wetlands Trail

parking lot: 313 Ellis Hollow Creek Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Good loop trail system with varied terrain and lots of tree variety.
nice easy trail. beautiful woods. lightly trafficked. in autumn, leaves on trails can hide roots that one can easily trip over.

I did this hike backward and I found a few spots difficult to navigate, especially at one point there is a road and someone's driveway, it got a little confusing. There were a lot of good inclines, but following this trail, my hike was about a mile longer than what it says on alltrails.

Great hike with well marked paths in a wooded area. We went in the morning and it wasn't nearly as popular as other hikes in the area.  There are a couple different routes to follow. Going clockwise, the 1.6 mile loop follows the yellow tail, then blue trail, then red trail.
Nice hike in the woods. Dogs are welcome- not sure why it says no dogs on the app. Some steep areas and lots of roots. Well marked and maintained. A few cute creeks.
Definitely a favorite! So many frogs and salamanders today. We usually go clockwise but I think I like this way better.
Great short trail. Lots of ups and downs and little creek crossings. Kind of a drag when the energy plant is being noisy, but that is rare.
A very peaceful, secluded spot. It's not crowded, even on weekends. Even though the loop is short, there are steep slopes that make it somewhat challenging.
Nice trail, great for kids if you follow the “Story book” trail. A book to read and creek to get feet wet..  my kids love it!
Great loop trail, however if you follow the red trail, which is part of this loop, I would rate it as moderate. Well marked, enjoy the stream crossings.
Fun walk in the woods with some minor climbs. Mostly peaceful, some brooks to cross although most were dry when we were here (July). Good place for a run. Nothing mind blowing, but good solitude.

Friends and I took our kids, including a four and a six year old, on a warmish day in January. There was enough mud, stream crossings, and slippery leaf cover on steepish slopes to make the trail feel kid unfriendly. It was a little much for them, but I think that wouldn’t be the case in the drier summer and fall months when the ground would be easier to walk upon. I found it a great trail myself, perfect for taking a decent yet not-too-long walk without having to backtrack.

We stumbled across this site using All Trails and were glad we did. We were in the area and looking for a short trail run and hike and this was perfect. It is a quiet forested area with opportunities for wildlife and peace. A local poet has posted some of their works throughout the system which was neat too. The main loop is about 1.5 miles and there are two shorter loops so you can easily cover about 3 miles or so if you do all three. We spotted a large owl and some neat salamanders/newts on our run. The trail is well marked and easy for trail running. There is a little elevation gain as well.  Would definitely go back if we are ever in the area again.
One my most favorite spots to just unwind. Would recommend this one to anyone

An excellent trail that is usually not busy.  You start with a strange walk alongside the power plant, but quickly dive into the trees and can enjoy the quiet babbling of the creek running next to the trail.  There are a couple different sized loops and they are minimally strenuous, but there are a couple good, short climbs that can get your heart rate up.  I would definitely recommend this hike, especially around sunset.

Unlike Eldridge Nature Preserve in which I got lost last time and which has the similar trail length as this one.. the trail was well-marked and it was obvious that a lot of people use this trail.  I didn't come across with anyone however, only one extra car in the parking area.  That car was gone by the time I came out of the forest.  It's a nice quick place to getaway that's not too far from Ithaca.

Monkey Run Trail.Name: Monkey Run Trail
Monkey Run Trail.Description: Cornell Botanic Gardens 550-acre Monkey Run Natural Area is a very popular hiking destination and is part of a long natural corridor protecting Fall Creek on its route to Cayuga Lake. Trails here, which connect with the Cayuga Trail, follow the creek from the rims of forested banks and at creek level through rich floodplain forest, seeps, and wet meadows. Breathtaking views are afforded from atop 100-foot bluffs, which are continually eroded by a meandering Fall Creek below.

parking lot: 1711 Hanshaw Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Awesome hike in early April. Great views and feels very removed despite being a 10 minute drive from Ithaca. Highly suggest doing the loop counter clockwise (follow the red markers first and then the orange). Pro tip: record your trip on AllTrails so you can see if you’re on the right trail because there are lots of offshoots.

We intended to follow the advice about going counterclockwise. However we took a wrong turn following the red trail markers and ended up way off our intended trail. It was a nice trail, so we kept going. We ended up on the Cayuga trail and found our way back to the parking lot. Determined to do the correct trail we kept walking and stayed on trail, and doubled our mileage. Great hike.
Blue sky and warm weather ;)

Not easy to follow in the field especially in winter.  If you take the loop counter clockwise take red to the field and then pick up orange by Dryden Rd. Just past the orange fire hydrant and the orange building, follow orange back to the starting point.
This is an excellent trail.   Snow packed, not too slippery.   Lots of elevation changes.
Beautiful trail along the creek, mix of elevation change, nothing difficult.
Great view
Great loop, nice views especially with the snow! Started clockwise and got the pretty views of the creek toward the second half of the loop.
Loved it

Parking located at end of Monkey Run Rd. Conditions are great, icy, and if hiking in a clockwise direction spikes would have been good the last half mile. Latter half of the hike in this direction walks along fall creek and close to some steep cliffs. When intersecting with the Cayuga Trail, there are not clear markings with regard to which direction to proceed, however studying the map will show waking toward rte 366 is the way to go.  At this point the trail heads from west to northeast through a flat field, follow the woods line on the left which will bring you back to what looks like a marked trail. Note that at this point the markers change from orange to red. Following the red markers bring you around to complete the loop.
A little confusing trail markers (orange & red blazes), but beautiful trail, even in the winter.

We did it clockwise, which I recommend. Orange flares until you get to the field, then follow red. First mile is a little confusing and not very scenic. The rest is beautiful, great views. Extremely steep drop to the creek below so be careful. We had a sunny day so it was great!
great day on the Monkey Run trails in Ithaca New York....great scenery and not a ton of slippery leaves

We did the loop clockwise, and it was a fine hike. The trail marks start out orange. Others talked about the field being confusing. When you first come out of the woods, turn right. You’ll come out into the field. After you walk a ways, you’ll notice a tree line off to the left. Work your way to it and follow it. You’ll come to a trail entrance with red trail marks. Follow that. Great views of the creek.

Gorgeous, pretty easy 3 mile hike without much climbing. Using the map in this app, we didn’t run into any of the navigation issues others have reported. We went clockwise, and the trail blazes shift from orange to red while you’re in the open field area. FYI for your GPS, the gravel parking area we used is at 31 Monkey Run Road. IMPORTANT WARNING: do a thorough tick check of your dogs!! My friend found multiple ticks on each of her three dogs. (No ticks on the humans.)

Beautiful trail. Has everything I want in a trail. Ups and downs and beautiful scenery!  Markers are good except when at field. Had to use app to find where it went again. Dont let that discourage you though, it was well worth a few minutes of confusion. Just get your app out when you get to the field. And part of the trail is red markers and part is yellowish orange. Also.. this trail is not 2.6 miles as description indicates. It is a bit longer. I am not sure who figures out the miles but I am finding that several of the mile reports are not correct with this app.
pretty trail. a little difficult to follow at times. didn't really like the portions along the road or through the field.

Gorgeous views, so peaceful and scenic. A nice moderately challenging trail. The only downside is that the loop trail gets a tad confusing. Be aware that if you go right on the trail from the parking lot to start the markers are all red until you cross the open field and pick up a trail along Dryden rd., then the markers switch to orange.
Section of the trail wasn’t clearly marked. We had to keep our phone out with the app open to be able to stay on! Other than that it was pretty with lots of nice views.
would not recommend going after dark...

Great adventure with a five year old. Not a problem to navigate with pretty views along the creek and cliffs. Enjoyed exploring the creek area and saw multiple herons along the creek. Well marked trail while in the woods but needed to follow the map on All Trails to know where to go when in open spaces. The child loved being in the woods before and after but not a fan of walking through the field. Would do this again!
Easy, scenic fun hike. Through forests, cliffs and next to a creek for most of it. We had a great time.
Loved it! Keep your map open!
great, but very easy to go off trail
Great trail!  No bugs, no mud.  Check your map - there are a lot of side trails.
Very nice trail, especially down by the creek, which is accessible in places. Trails can be confusing, so use the app to make sure you're on the right path.
Not too muddy even after some rain. Pretty empty before noon too.

Overall, it’s pretty good. Things to know before you go: 1.) if you’ve never done it, use telemetry. Without the Recording feature we would never have found our way, so whoever said it first, thanks, it’s good advice. 2.) the prescribed route is not 2.4 miles, it’s about 3.6. 3.) for about half a mile you’re edging a field, which is kinda boring for kids. 4.) sometimes you’re following yellow blazes, sometimes red. See also: #1. Altogether worth the effort though.
Very pretty, but the trail markings can get confusing because there’s multiple offshoots. Definitely recommend recording your trip to stay on the right path.
Beautiful misty morning with great creek and cliff views.
It was a lovely walk with my 3 and 5 year old children. 90% of the walk is well shaded. We cut across to the river at a certain point and enjoyed cooking our feet in the very gentle current.
Great trail with great views along the way. A bit overgrown at parts and with lots of roots in the way. I would recommend following the map carefully as it is easy to make a wrong turn.
Fun, easy trail. Beautiful day, beautiful scenery and only encountered a few people.  We ended up walking 4 miles because there are a few trails to walk on here.
Beautiful, but very heavily trafficked.

updated: I appreciate the rating change to Moderate as there are many roots, steep inclines, and poor marking at times -. This started out to be an amazing trail. WOW! Part gorge trail, part rim trail, part forest hike. I parked on the dead end Monkey Run Rd. and entered the trail opposite the parking spaces (I hiked counter clockwise) and quickly got off the trail. Now, most of the trail is well marked with red, but there are many many off shoots. At first start I ended up on part of the Cayuga Trail, but it easily loops back (see my recording for all the side ventures). The views along Fall Creek are AMAZING, just watch your step along the cliffs (they're bound to erode one of these days). Upon exiting the forest and walking along the meadow, it was a nice field walk, but then the red markers stopped and that's when it got confusing. I had missed the mention of this before I set out. I ended up walking quite a bit on a dirt road apparently following the Cayuga Trail with the yellow markers and finally saw where Monkey Run Trail went back into the forest on the left.  But this was still marked yellow - never again to see the red markers.  I don't generally do trails more than once (because there's just so many!) but this was a great walk in the woods and next time, I'd make it an out and back up to the field.  Use the All Trails map that tracks your progress. Some of the off-shoots yielded spectacular views - be sure to venture down to Fall Creek when you can and see the cliffs from the bottom.  Better marking for Monkey Run Trail would have made this a perfect hike.  Best advice, keep an eye on the map. At one point as I was near the end on the Cayuga Trail walking up the dirt road and All Trails notified me that my trail was complete! Hardly! I still had a ways to go.
Trail markers change from red to orange, we had to keep a close eye on our map because we kept ending up off trail. Beautiful hike though
Recommend the red trail along Fall Creek. Stunning.
This trail was the biggest surprise of my impromptu vacation to the region. Close to town, not as crowded as many trails in the area, wide variety of views and dog-friendly. Quite a gem.

Wonderful trail close to Ithaca. Monkey Run is an underrated gem of a hiking area as it has some of the most intriguing scenery in the region, from towering cliffs to peaceful forests. It is a little muddy in spots but not much overall. I highly recommend!

Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Trolley Bridge.Name: Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Trolley Bridge
Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Trolley Bridge.Description: The iconic Cornell Botanic Gardens Cascadilla Gorge Trail connects downtown Ithaca with the Cornell Campus among one of the most picturesque gorges in the Finger Lakes Region and was voted Ithaca's favorite gorge.  Ascending over 400 feet, this historic set of stone trails and staircases was originally constructed in the late 1920's, and takes visitors through the gorge formed from ancient bedrock and past six waterfalls.  At a leisurely pace, this 1/3-mile section of the trail takes less than an hour from the Treman Triangle Park in downtown to the upper entrance by the College Avenue Stone Arch Bridge. In Collegetown, the trail crosses College Avenue and the Goldwin Smith Walk continues to follow Cascadilla Creek for another half mile through a flat, wooded area that leads to two footbridges over scenic waterfalls. The lower gorge from Linn St to College Ave is closed during the winter months, but the gorge above College Ave is open year round.

parking lot: Hoy Rd. Parking Garage

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Very nice! Steep steps but quick
Meh. Just do the lower unless you want a short nature walk w college students.
Well maintained. Beautiful gem in the middle of Ithaca.
Pleasant walking trail around Cornell.
Hit this on out way out of town for a little extra something. Fun, beautiful. Cornell students are lucky!
Quick loop to add onto Cascadilla trails - fun add on! Well maintained
This was my favorite waterfall hike in Ithaca. Lots of stars but there are so many beautiful things to see that there are plenty of places to stop and take in the sights. I cant wait to come back.
Nice shady walk through the trees & along the creek.  Pretty area.
Eh. It was ok. The full trail was closed.

This is an extension of the Lower Cascadilla Gorge Trail from Downtown Ithaca. It is a nice, wooded gorge with a few waterfalls. The loop is short but scenic. I recommend doing this only as a continuation of the Lower Gorge Trail, as it is not worth a separate visit.

Palmer Woods Trail.Name: Palmer Woods Trail
Palmer Woods Trail.Description: This trail provides an easy-to-access scenic escape in Cornell's North Campus. Much of Cornell Botanic Gardens Palmer Woods Natural Area is a mature forest, dominated by large oaks. Trails here also cross strips of young forest that were once fairways of Cornell's Robert Trent Jones golf course and open meadow. It will take about an hour to explore the network of trails in this area, which is known to be a good bird watching site.

parking lot: Cornell A Lot

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Couldn't really find the first part of the trail. Some red plastic markers on trees. Followed a path of footsteps. The end was well trodden and well marked with red paint.
got lost :( got muddy :(
Hiked in the late evening, so it was even harder to find my way. At a certain point I couldn’t find the trail again, so I packed up and went home. Will try again when it’s light.
Not well marked. Easy to get off the trail.

Great forest oasis in midst of residential neighborhood. With the little stream running through the forest, the small swampy area, and the grassy field, there’s a wide variety of habitats - super for birding.
This is a nice short walk near Cornell. There isn't much scenery in terms of views but the trails through the forest are pretty and well-maintained.

Monkey Run Trail - CRC Access.Name: Monkey Run Trail - CRC Access
Monkey Run Trail - CRC Access.Description: Cornell Botanic Gardens 550-acre Monkey Run Natural Area is a very popular hiking destination and is part of a long natural corridor protecting Fall Creek on its route to Cayuga Lake. Trails here, which connect with the Cayuga Trail, follow the creek from the rims of forested banks and at creek level through rich floodplain forest, seeps, and wet meadows. Breathtaking views are afforded from atop 100-foot bluffs, which are continually eroded by a meandering Fall Creek below.

parking lot: 1711 Hanshaw Rd.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Awesome hike in early April. Great views and feels very removed despite being a 10 minute drive from Ithaca. Highly suggest doing the loop counter clockwise (follow the red markers first and then the orange). Pro tip: record your trip on AllTrails so you can see if you’re on the right trail because there are lots of offshoots.

We intended to follow the advice about going counterclockwise. However we took a wrong turn following the red trail markers and ended up way off our intended trail. It was a nice trail, so we kept going. We ended up on the Cayuga trail and found our way back to the parking lot. Determined to do the correct trail we kept walking and stayed on trail, and doubled our mileage. Great hike.
Blue sky and warm weather ;)

Not easy to follow in the field especially in winter.  If you take the loop counter clockwise take red to the field and then pick up orange by Dryden Rd. Just past the orange fire hydrant and the orange building, follow orange back to the starting point.
This is an excellent trail.   Snow packed, not too slippery.   Lots of elevation changes.
Beautiful trail along the creek, mix of elevation change, nothing difficult.
Great view
Great loop, nice views especially with the snow! Started clockwise and got the pretty views of the creek toward the second half of the loop.
Loved it

Parking located at end of Monkey Run Rd. Conditions are great, icy, and if hiking in a clockwise direction spikes would have been good the last half mile. Latter half of the hike in this direction walks along fall creek and close to some steep cliffs. When intersecting with the Cayuga Trail, there are not clear markings with regard to which direction to proceed, however studying the map will show waking toward rte 366 is the way to go.  At this point the trail heads from west to northeast through a flat field, follow the woods line on the left which will bring you back to what looks like a marked trail. Note that at this point the markers change from orange to red. Following the red markers bring you around to complete the loop.
A little confusing trail markers (orange & red blazes), but beautiful trail, even in the winter.

We did it clockwise, which I recommend. Orange flares until you get to the field, then follow red. First mile is a little confusing and not very scenic. The rest is beautiful, great views. Extremely steep drop to the creek below so be careful. We had a sunny day so it was great!
great day on the Monkey Run trails in Ithaca New York....great scenery and not a ton of slippery leaves

We did the loop clockwise, and it was a fine hike. The trail marks start out orange. Others talked about the field being confusing. When you first come out of the woods, turn right. You’ll come out into the field. After you walk a ways, you’ll notice a tree line off to the left. Work your way to it and follow it. You’ll come to a trail entrance with red trail marks. Follow that. Great views of the creek.

Gorgeous, pretty easy 3 mile hike without much climbing. Using the map in this app, we didn’t run into any of the navigation issues others have reported. We went clockwise, and the trail blazes shift from orange to red while you’re in the open field area. FYI for your GPS, the gravel parking area we used is at 31 Monkey Run Road. IMPORTANT WARNING: do a thorough tick check of your dogs!! My friend found multiple ticks on each of her three dogs. (No ticks on the humans.)

Beautiful trail. Has everything I want in a trail. Ups and downs and beautiful scenery!  Markers are good except when at field. Had to use app to find where it went again. Dont let that discourage you though, it was well worth a few minutes of confusion. Just get your app out when you get to the field. And part of the trail is red markers and part is yellowish orange. Also.. this trail is not 2.6 miles as description indicates. It is a bit longer. I am not sure who figures out the miles but I am finding that several of the mile reports are not correct with this app.
pretty trail. a little difficult to follow at times. didn't really like the portions along the road or through the field.

Gorgeous views, so peaceful and scenic. A nice moderately challenging trail. The only downside is that the loop trail gets a tad confusing. Be aware that if you go right on the trail from the parking lot to start the markers are all red until you cross the open field and pick up a trail along Dryden rd., then the markers switch to orange.
Section of the trail wasn’t clearly marked. We had to keep our phone out with the app open to be able to stay on! Other than that it was pretty with lots of nice views.
would not recommend going after dark...

Great adventure with a five year old. Not a problem to navigate with pretty views along the creek and cliffs. Enjoyed exploring the creek area and saw multiple herons along the creek. Well marked trail while in the woods but needed to follow the map on All Trails to know where to go when in open spaces. The child loved being in the woods before and after but not a fan of walking through the field. Would do this again!
Easy, scenic fun hike. Through forests, cliffs and next to a creek for most of it. We had a great time.
Loved it! Keep your map open!
great, but very easy to go off trail
Great trail!  No bugs, no mud.  Check your map - there are a lot of side trails.
Very nice trail, especially down by the creek, which is accessible in places. Trails can be confusing, so use the app to make sure you're on the right path.
Not too muddy even after some rain. Pretty empty before noon too.

Overall, it’s pretty good. Things to know before you go: 1.) if you’ve never done it, use telemetry. Without the Recording feature we would never have found our way, so whoever said it first, thanks, it’s good advice. 2.) the prescribed route is not 2.4 miles, it’s about 3.6. 3.) for about half a mile you’re edging a field, which is kinda boring for kids. 4.) sometimes you’re following yellow blazes, sometimes red. See also: #1. Altogether worth the effort though.
Very pretty, but the trail markings can get confusing because there’s multiple offshoots. Definitely recommend recording your trip to stay on the right path.
Beautiful misty morning with great creek and cliff views.
It was a lovely walk with my 3 and 5 year old children. 90% of the walk is well shaded. We cut across to the river at a certain point and enjoyed cooking our feet in the very gentle current.
Great trail with great views along the way. A bit overgrown at parts and with lots of roots in the way. I would recommend following the map carefully as it is easy to make a wrong turn.
Fun, easy trail. Beautiful day, beautiful scenery and only encountered a few people.  We ended up walking 4 miles because there are a few trails to walk on here.
Beautiful, but very heavily trafficked.

Trail markers change from red to orange, we had to keep a close eye on our map because we kept ending up off trail. Beautiful hike though
Recommend the red trail along Fall Creek. Stunning.
This trail was the biggest surprise of my impromptu vacation to the region. Close to town, not as crowded as many trails in the area, wide variety of views and dog-friendly. Quite a gem.

Wonderful trail close to Ithaca. Monkey Run is an underrated gem of a hiking area as it has some of the most intriguing scenery in the region, from towering cliffs to peaceful forests. It is a little muddy in spots but not much overall. I highly recommend!

Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Crescent Entran.Name: Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Crescent Entrance
Cascadilla Gorge Trail - Crescent Entran.Description: The iconic Cornell Botanic Gardens Cascadilla Gorge Trail connects downtown Ithaca with the Cornell Campus among one of the most picturesque gorges in the Finger Lakes Region and was voted Ithaca's favorite gorge. street: Linn St. or E Court St.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: No
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Very nice! Steep steps but quick
Meh. Just do the lower unless you want a short nature walk w college students.
Well maintained. Beautiful gem in the middle of Ithaca.
Pleasant walking trail around Cornell.
Hit this on out way out of town for a little extra something. Fun, beautiful. Cornell students are lucky!
Quick loop to add onto Cascadilla trails - fun add on! Well maintained
This was my favorite waterfall hike in Ithaca. Lots of stars but there are so many beautiful things to see that there are plenty of places to stop and take in the sights. I cant wait to come back.
Nice shady walk through the trees & along the creek.  Pretty area.
Eh. It was ok. The full trail was closed.

This is an extension of the Lower Cascadilla Gorge Trail from Downtown Ithaca. It is a nice, wooded gorge with a few waterfalls. The loop is short but scenic. I recommend doing this only as a continuation of the Lower Gorge Trail, as it is not worth a separate visit.

Taughannock Falls South Rim Trail.Name: Taughannock Falls South Rim Trail

parking lot: NY 89, eight miles north of Ithaca to the Main Entrance.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Did the North Rim trail first, and then the Gorge trail, and then the South Rim trail. Beautiful views, even in the rain! Everything was clearly marked and the trails were well maintained. Maybe just watch out for the slippery rock steps when it's rainy.

Was a beautiful day trail was clear and marked. Recommend going early morning  by 1030 trail was getting busy.  We actually started on the south rim which met up to North rim and really enjoyed the views along the way.
Best scenic trail for amazing views!!!
Stunning views of the falls! A must see!
A little muddy, blue bird day, cool temps.

Absolutely wonderful. I suggest starting on North rim trail as it is basically uphill the whole way and less scenic than south, but definitely still worth the trip amazing view points. Once you get half way there is another trail it is the gorge trail out and back very heavily trafficked. The gorge trail is like nothing we’ve seen before, seeing the rock layers up close and the ability to walk on the rock of the fall.
Great views of the falls!
A little muddy in spots. Beautiful March day!
Pretty views, well walked path with lots of waterfall views. Only did the north rim, there and back because the south rim trail was closed at the entrance of the mail falls park.

This really is an easy trail unless you have bad knees... it's gravel/ paved all along. There are steps at the end, but only about three flights.  Assuming you do both rims and the gorge trail, I'd recommend the North rim first, which has views of the falls.  Seeing them from a distance is really exciting and builds the anticipation!  Then do the gorge trail.  Then do the South Rim to finish up.    We took about 2 1/2 hours to do this full loop, including the gorge trail to the base of the falls, and didn't particularly rush.
Awesome 1st day of the year hike  Short and sweet love Ithaca

Enjoyable hike/walk through the woods with views of the gorge and falls. We did the North Rim first, then the gorge trail (out and back) and then used the South Rim trail to bring us back to where we parked.
Great moderate hike, good for someone looking to prep for the Adirondacks.  The steeper parts, give you an idea.  Great waterfalls, trails are well paved.

Great moderate hike! We started on the South Trail and looped over to the North Trail after doing the quick Gorge Trail. So glad we did that because the surprise views along the way really made the day well spent!

Made the most out of a rainy day, so of course there was no one on the trail! I would rate it a moderate hike because of the stairs that you had to climb a few times. Also do the North rim trail first and then the south rim. I think that's the best way to get the full experience of the loop!
It’s like a walk in the park. I don’t mean it’s easy - well, it’s moderately challenging-  but it’s not terribly scenic with wire fencing all along the gorge.
Lots of steps to start and then rewarded with a beautiful view and fairly flat trail
Still fairly crowded on weekends, especially the gorge trail and overlook.  Lots of turkey vultures flying around in easy view from North Rim. Good mask wearing in late October though.

Fall colors not quite peak but still amazing. The Trail on both north and south is well maintained with very little root trip hazards. Incline intense in short burst at lake end of both trail heads but not entire trail so don’t worry. It is easier to start on the south trail heading west than it was the north trail. If you are starting on the west side parking lot then take the north trail first. The incline on the north trail on the east side is pretty long compared to the south trail on the east side. $8 parking per car at east side through Oct 18th then free after that. Highly suggest bringing your trekking poles, made it must more enjoyable on moderate trails.
Nice short flat trail at the bottom ,,.. beautiful View
Beautiful view of the falls, but they were just a trickle at this time of year.

I prefer this trail over the Gorge trail in the park! Multiple gorgeous views from above and FREE parking in the visitor center lot! (If you go down to the Gorge trailhead/picnic area it's $10 I think)
Pro tip: the trail intersects the Gorge Trail so if you’re going to do both, park there instead.   Also, the falls face west so go in the morning for better pictures.
Exceeded expectations
Beautiful. Tough trek back, as either side has some serious stairs to climb. Views are gorges on the South Rim. A bit more tourists on the North Rim, since they can pull up, park, and view the falls.
Loved the hike and views.
Beautiful the fall colors are excellent. I plan on coming back to see all seasons I unless you want  a  up hill climb start down north rim and come up south
Amazing geology! Amazing views! Well maintained trail makes for easy hike except for cardio workout of climbing stairs. Heavily traveled but that's because it's so interesting.
Footpath is easy and stairs down to gorge
Great hike. Went on one of the Labor Day week. Falls water dried up but visible from view point.
Stairs like mad at lake ends. Just easy hike otherwise. Amazing views.
Did North and South Rim and Gorge trails and it was awesome! Not difficult at all and it took a little less than two and a half hours. Definitely recommend!
Beautiful views especially on the North Rim trail. Would have been better in the spring with more water coming over the falls but still a good hike
Beautiful trail with incredible views. I recommend including the 1.5 mile up and back to walk to the waterfall.
it was not bad. nothing special.

easy path to follow, gorgeous views, especially of taughannock falls on north rim. a bit of road noise at parts, but mostly peaceful and quiet. lots of stairs at the beginning / end of loop, but most of the actual path is fairly flat.  no crowding at all!

Awesome hike. Well worth it.  Start from the lake, take the entrance with the arch and climb from there. The hike is challenging due to the steep steps - the trail itself is very well maintained. Several nice viewpoints along the way but a lot of trees tend to block the best views.
very nice hike!
Clear. Fall was pretty dry.

Trail was just ok. Good elevation at the beginning if you like that (which I do). The waterfall was cool (although not a lot of water right now) but you can also just drive to the viewing point on the north rim - or do the gorge trail for best views.
Nice trail that is well maintained. Completed with 5 and 8 year old boys and a dog
Amazing what 380 million years will do to our earth.  People are good about wearing mask & keeping 6' apart.  BTW, North rim is mostly up hill.  Bring water.
We went on May 13th. We didn’t get to do the gorge because it was closed at the time. But the rim trails were awesome!! Recommend it to all. We need to go back to do the gorge trail.

Great trail. Amazing views. Took opposite route and started at the base by the lake on the south trail and returned via the north trail. $8 for parking. Hundreds were on the gorge trail but only 40-50 people on the rim trail.
Not too crowded on the upper trails, nice summer hike
Amazing  Moderate because  There were some parts Where It was straight incline  Even though it wasn’t t bad at all  I’ll be back

We started at the bottom in the lake parking lot, went up the South Rim trail & came down North Rim trail. Trail is well marked. I’ve done the Gorge Trail several times so it was great to get a different perspective of the falls. Steep stairs at the start, but levels out after that.
Best hiking trails, well groomed and clearly marked. Excellent hiking experience with my two dogs and my two sons-3 and 10 years old.

There are a lot more people situated near the water at the entrance. You can walk over and walk in the water. The loop was fun! There were great views and everything is well labeled. The stairs can be a little steep but you only have to worry about them at the beginning/end of the north and south rim trail.

The streps were steep but you get some beautiful views of the falls and the lake from way up high!  The main parking lot has cones in every other spot to promote social distancing so get here early if you want to park at the State Park lot.

beautiful views from a well maintained trail. started up the south rim, and there's a bunch of stairs. looks like there's an alternate route for the descent of the north rim that avoids stairs, which we will take next time. it levels out pretty quickly.  took us 2 hours, but I weigh close to 400lbs and my hiking buddy/wife is getting a total hip replacement next month. for people of size or with joint issues, a set of walking sticks might make all the difference between an enjoyable hike or abject agony. we can't wait to walk it again
nice. easy lots of stairs. so enjoyable. a must. takes about 2 hours with small kids

Despite the closure, this trail is still worth visiting. The experience of viewing the gorge from so high up and from so many angles is an unbearably unique experience. Would recommend going the North Rim way around towards the Falls Overlook Center, as the South Rim is closed about halfway in.
Definitely easy trail. A lot of the trails that were close
Heavy traffic, close to the road. But the views are amazing, took an hour and a half to do the round trip started on the south rim
Fun and easy 3 mile hike. Some cool views and nice kept trail. Took 1 hour to finish

One of my favorite trails in the Finger Lakes. The views are terrific, it’s well maintained, it has two (two!) real bathrooms. It is mostly shaded. And the falls themselves are amazing, but so is the gorge both above and below, as well as the hints of Cayuga Lake through the trees!!  What more could you ask for??!!  Thank you NY state for maintaining and improving this trail over the years!!

5 star views, 3 star trail. The landscape around the waterfall and cascades is spectacular, however the trail itself is next to a road for most of the way. The trail itself is in good condition and an easy, rather than moderate walk, despite the elevation.
We hiked the south rim trail to the North rim trail.  Several steps at the beginning but a lot of level trail as well.  Excellent views of the waterfall from above.
Really enjoyed this walk! Beautiful gorge with a leisurely stroll.
Nice, easy trail along the rim. There's a 400 foot climb/descent, but otherwise, it's pretty casual.
Overcrowded and way too urban. North rim wasn’t bad, but made the mistake of going into the Gorge Trail with 10,000 of my closest friends. Beautiful falls, but a Sunday stroll, not a hike.
Beautiful view of the falls.Even saw an eagle.
Did only a short part of this trail. Maybe in the future, I'd like to go back to do the whole thing.
South rim seemed overall less steep.  Gorgeous views all the way around.

This was a amazing hike with gorgeous sight and views of the gorge and falls. It took me about two hours to do the whole rim trail, starting and ending at the overlook. It was about 3.2 miles total, but I had forgotten to turn off the recording before driving back down to the gorge entrance. It is tough and tiring towards the bottom going up either direction due to many steep steps and inclined to have to climb, but it was definitely worth it! I’ll be back for sure
Great hike with dogs. Good altitude gain and beautiful waterfalls.
Wonderful waterfalls. Highly recommend follow the South and North Rim Trail .i love it .
Beautiful easy and scenic
Started at the bottom and went up the south rim.  Steps weren’t bad at all!  Beautiful views, well marked trail. Overall a fun hike!
Hiked the start of the north rim in the campground and walked around. Great day for a hike!
Love this trail - did this with 3 dogs in August. It was hot and the stairs are killer but will do this again!
This trail is gorge-ous
Hopefully this will be one of many.

We recommend the South Trail, North Rim Trail then the Falls Trail as well. Lots of great views, hot today so we took a lot of water. Lots of areas to sit and rest. Watch the heat folks! There is a lot of shade.
Great views of the gorge and very shaded for hot days.

Hiked the rim trails and the gorge trail on one of the hottest days of the year. Today, the rim trails were not very busy. I recommended starting with the South Rim, then the North Rim and end with the Gorge trail.

Taughannock Rim trail.  While the gorge trail is spectacular, this was the hike I was looking for to get a workout. Yes, it's rated as moderate, but the steps going up (and then coming back down) will challenge those small muscles above your knees! It was a bit disorienting when emerging at the overlook from way above - I wasn't sure where the rim trail picked back up (no signage until you get much closer) but I figured it out - just keep along rim :) A great hike around the gorge, for sure.

While the gorge trail is spectacular, this was the hike I was looking for to get a workout.  Yes, it's rated as moderate, but the steps going up (and then coming back down) will challenge those small muscles above your knees! It was a bit disorienting when emerging at the overlook from way above - I wasn't sure where the rim trail picked back up (no signage until you get much closer) but I figured it out - just keep along rim :)  A great hike around the gorge, for sure.
Did the South Rim Trail to the Gorge. Good sights from above into the gorge, but inside the gorge is way better.
Beautiful trail! The gorge trail is a necessary addition in my opinion!

Nice long round trip. Added the gorge trail to make the total trip close to 5 Miles. This park is a great mix of good hiking, great views of the gorge and falls, and some touristy park areas if you want to hang out for the day, picnic, swim, etc.  The hardest part is the steps in either direction on the east side as you ascend to the rim. The rest is relatively flat.

Absolutely loved the hike. I just wish I knew what I had gotten myself into originally. Turns out there is a road through the park that will take you down to the base of the waterfall. I started at the top around the Rim and found myself hiking down and THEN traversing across towards the base of the waterfall. Won’t make that mistake twice...
Good for those that want the views as well as a more moderate hike
Fun sight seeing hike with amazing view points of the highest waterfall in NY.
Beautiful trail. Nice views of the gorge and waterfall. Part of it was closed but there was an alternate route so it was okay!
We went halfway through the trail and saw it was closed so we continued on the side of the street. I was pretty bummed we couldn't do the whole thing.
An absolutely beautiful trail that gives you a great look at the gorges and the falls below.  One of my favorite trails!
Tried hiking the south rim. It was icy, but not bad with micro spikes. It was closed one mile in. So I did part of the north rim. Decent view of the falls. Not too crowded.
totally awesome even in November.

It’s definitely a decent hike. We started on the North Rim, went to the Gorge Trail. We hiked back up through the Sound Rim trail back to the car. 5.2 miles in total. The views are amazing and there are most definitely smaller and more exciting trails to take.
We did the rim trail and then the falls. Beautiful late summer hike, mid 70's, still good water flow over the falls. 5 miles, 2 hours, 1,063 elevation change. One of our favorites!

Buttermilk Falls Bear Trail.Name: Buttermilk Falls Bear Trail
Buttermilk Falls Bear Trail.Description: Buttermilk Creek drops 600 feet as it plunges through a gorge down the eastern slope of the Cayuga Valley at the southernmost edge of the City of Ithaca. Five trails in the park wander through a remarkable variety of landscapes.

parking lot: NY-13 S/NY-34 S/NY-96 S/Elmira Rd, 3 miles south of Ithaca (Lower/Main Park Trailhead).

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: The east Treman trail is closed, but it isnt marked as such from the South. Gorge trail is closed and dangerous.
One way trail rules going on for CV19.

Get there early in the morning on a weekday and you shouldn’t see too many other people. It’s infuriating to see people STILL not wearing masks and please say something to them if you feel comfortable doing so. Overall very peaceful and beautiful hike!
Super cool views with low hanging clouds. Very wet and muddy but nothing a good pair of hiking boots can’t handle

Lots of uphill on this hike and not really too much to see in terms of views compared to other hikes in the area but overall a nice stroll through nature! Lake and falls are pretty dried up this time of year so I'd recommend going to Treman State Park instead if you're chasing falls
Very nice trail, especially once you get past all the people who only do the Gorge. Fall colors were beautiful. Water level was down due to the lack of rain.
Great!

Nice 5.6 mile loop, took about 3 hrs. Rim trail is peaceful and steep, lake Treman is fairly empty but a nice quiet loop, the waterfalls along Gorges trail are so beautiful. More than a few hikers going the wrong way around the one-way loop, have a mask handy, but the foliage is great and a great half day hike
Nicely maintained. One way loop. Not too crowded on a Monday September morning. Great views.
late September the leaves haven't changed much, check the lake trail in the coming weeks for some gorgeous colors!
Beautiful, can’t wait to come back to see the falls streaming with water.
Lake pretty dry.  Falls great

Nice trail. Almost all of the elevation is in the first mile or so of this trail. The water levels are very low with the current drought situation but the Gorge Trail portion of the hike was still stunning while the rest was just ok. This would be gorgeous in springtime!
Very family friendly, however it was a bit crowded. Also due to COVID there was one designated direction up and one down.
I can’t believe I forgot how wonderful this trail is. Definitely one of the more crowded in the area, but I can understand why.

it was a good hike, very enjoyable not too strenuous great views lots of waterfalls, many people on the trail go early, Waterway is slightly dried up but some of the waterfalls are still functioning. would recommend took  3 hours
This hike gives you a little bit of everything. It’s not too much an elevation climb. You get a bit of everything on this hike. Wear waterproof shoes.

Great trail with all diff kinds of terrain. It was more like 6 miles, but with all the stops to take pictures and enjoy the views, it’s doesn’t feel that long.   Folks were enjoying the water in many locations, so come prepared if you want to get wet.   The parking was

Park gets crowded on weekends, after about 9 am a steady stream of people entering. Lake loop generally has fewer people. currently one way on the Gorge and Rim trails, although despite obvious signage probably 10-15% of the people ignore this.

Beautiful trail for a mostly easy stroll for experienced hikers and beginners alike. Gorges are gorgeous! No swimming anywhere at this time during Covid, unfortunately... Still worth the experience if you’re in the area.
Moderate Hike you can complete in under 2 hours.  Some great scenery.  Well kept trail.
Take bear path both up and down as the other side is a paved road

Didn’t record entire hike. Did Buttermilk falls rim, at top continued walking the park ‘road’ towards the lake but turned around at bear trail, came down bear trail to gorge trail. Total distance about 3.8 miles. Got there at noon on Sunday in August after driving from Baltimore. A disaster during Covid! Traffic was supposed to be one way (up rim, down gorge, like we did), where masks when within 6’ of others, signs everywhere stating this, but not only was it super crowded (no surprise), but sooooo many people not cooperating with signage. A gorgeous area otherwise. (We did have the park road and bear trail basically to ourselves).
Great trail and well marked steep at times but all worth it. Swim at the end is all worth it after a hard hike. Water temps is low 60’s. Will be back for more. Just one way due to Covid-19
Easy for the beginners

A pleasant not too challenging hike. Due to coronavirus you are told to star via gorge train and come down the rim trail. The rim trail was a nicer hike and had a nice stone observation area. We went off the observation area into the falls and stream in the gorge. This trail also has quite a few moments on paved roads or carriage trails.
Excellent loop. The bear and lake trails are usually uncrowded and there are scenic views, especially on the lake trail.
Beautiful area, but the lake is really low today, and the bridge at the end is washed out.

Sad that gorge trail was closed, but still did hike via rim up and down again. No bug bites! Last time I did this hike was in July and we were eaten alive! Great hike with the dog and two teenagers. lots of places to stop by the water and cool off when needed. Sometimes hard to distance when the path became narrow, but not too many tight spots and people very respectful of space. Can't wait for gorge to be opened again - its so lovely to climb right next to the waterfall.
Nice trail. Always in the mood for some falls! Gorge trail closed but still a good hike.
Bridge out, can still get around it. Gorge trail closed so you sort of have to come back the way you came but nice overall trail

This was a fun hike. Signs are posted that the bridge is out on the lake trail but you can still cross the bridge it’s just covers in brush and missing an end section. Was able to cross without a problem.
Beautiful trail with amazing waterfalls and water flow.  The bridge at the end of the lake is out but it is passable.
One of our favorite hikes in the Finger Lakes area. A bit harder, but takes the cake over Watkins Glen!

Got to the trail early (8AM) and definitely avoided any crowds. We passed a few people on the gorge trail, but mostly it was incredibly serene. We parked at the lower park area and went up the gorge trail, down the rim trail. This was an amazing hike, full of lots of different kinds of nature’s beauty. There are many very steep climbs and stairs, so it was a workout for sure, but it was absolutely worth it.
Stone bridge at the top of Lake Treman was washed out by a massive pile of logs and debris. Been hiking Buttermilk for 20 years never seen anything like that before.
Fun trail with lots of elevation, some fairly steep.  We hiked the gorge trail and Bear trail.

Hiked Thursday afternoon, not very crowded. Started at the Lake trail, Bear trail, then to the Gorge trail. Beautiful waterfalls and scenery.  Stopped for water at the picnic area at the main Buttermilk Falls State Park picnic area, then headed up the Rim trail which was a tough all uphill trail. That led to a road which we did not want to hike, so we took the branch back down to the Gorge trail/Bear/Lake back to where we parked. Took us longer than we thought it would. About 2 hrs hiking pretty hard.
I agree with everything Mr Buxbaum said except that we started about 9 AM late August on a cloudy day and the main gorge trail was relatively uncrowded until our way back.  Great photos.

This trail was my favorite of them all! They make such a bike hype about Watkins Glen (neat too) but this is by far the most amazing and breath taking. Lucifer Falls is out of this world. We only did the gorge trail and part of the rim.

Went in the late morning/early afternoon on a Saturday. Nice couple hour hike. Moderate/easy, as their are some steps in the beginning/end. Gorge trail is a little crowded, but it wasn't overwhelmingly so. It seems like every few seconds, there's a new waterfall, so that's pretty cool. Once the Gorge Trail ends, the Bear Trail begins and the crowds thin out. Not as impressive as the Gorge, but the woods have their own charm. Treman Lake loop is pretty easy, though the bridge at the end of the loop is washed out. You either have to walk across 10 feet of shallow creek or turn around. I opted to walk across the creek and easily completed the walk back.

My husband and I did this hike yesterday with our dog. As the description denotes, it’s three separate trails strung one after another. The first part of the trail (Gorge) is super highly trafficked and can get slippery from the traffic on the weekends. We were able to keep our dog off leash on the later and more desolate areas of the hike (though you’re not supposed to). Would definitely recommend—it’s fairly challenging but the changing terrain made it very enjoyable.

my second favorite hike in the area. I usually do this loop in about 3 hrs (at a moderate pace with stops to enjoy the view). Wear shoes with good grip as the wet steps on the gorge trail do get slippery. I recommend going up the gorge trail and down the rim trail for the best views. It can get a bit buggy around the lake so bring some bugspray. All trails are well maintained. Note that the gorge and rim trails are closed in the winter, and during the peak season (spring-fall) there is an entrance fee of $8/car.

Went earlier in the season, April 17th. Terrific views for a relatively easy hike. Comparing to most of the ADK hikes, but elevation can be surprising if you are expecting a leisurely stroll. (Proposed to my now fiancee here!)
Excellent Trail, perfect for whole family and dog-friendly. Beautiful falls.
Trail was great!  Early stairs can be tough.

Great day hike. Took our dog with us. Most of the trail was relatively easy if you have a basic fitness level. Some sections with stairs will get the heart rate up for a few minutes. Beautiful waterfalls and geological features. Pretty busy on the Gorge Trail, but Rim, Bear and the Treman Lake loop were all less populated. Most of the better geological features and waterfalls are on Gorge.

The trail was steep at times with stairs to help on the steeper inclines. Some of the stairs were not in the best conditions but most of them look like they were put in within the last few years. The rim portion was rocky and had a lot of loose gravel which made the decline harder. Great hike overall, would be impossible with strollers.

The gorge section of the trail is definitely the most beautiful and it’s has the most stairs (closest to moderate part of the whole trail). The rim trail is calm and woodsy, pretty easy. The trail section around the lake is worth skipping, not much to look at but calm for a run or walk depending on what you’re looking for  Overall the full trail is easy. Very dog friendly. Weather was amazing! Waterfalls in full action. Would go back for the gorge and rim trail again!

What an absolute gem! We were a bit weary to do this because we were not up for a long hike but it’s has a couple points that you can turn around easily. I’d say, if you can’t make it to Watkins Glen, this is an amazing substitute. I’d recommend going up the right side of the first fall by the parking lot, up the steps. That has the best view where you walk along the falls.
Lovely day hike in Ithaca.  Gorge Trail was still closed - so we had to go around.  But a nice couple hours outside.
Well marked. Easy to park. Well maintained.
My favorite trail in the Ithaca area! Lake Treman is a treasure. We started out sunny and watched storm clouds roll in and managed to complete just as the rain started. It was epic for me and my dog!

Bear Trail on the Lake loop/Buttermilk is my favorite local hike. Different terrains, following water, easy and hard. Today was a bit icy being early March. I had to go off trail a lot but I still enjoyed it as always!
Did this loop with my dog on Christmas Eve day. It was beautiful and safe and fun. One side is closed for the winter, but the east side remains open and easy to navigate.

Waterfall after waterfall after waterfall! The gorge trail delivers endless beauty. Our dog loved it too. Took the rim trail back which gave great sunset light through the trees. Overall great walk in in the park lots of majesty for minimal to moderate effort.
Loop. Water . Light traffic during fall. Nice for picnics near the fall.

Great trail! I wouldn’t classify it as moderate closer to upper easy than moderate. However it was very beautiful the entire time! We started with the Rim Trail which merged into the Bear TrIl, then loops around the Lake and got back into the Gorge Trail. Took about 1 hour and 35 minutes or so. We had our dogs with us a long the way. There weren’t too many opportunities to let them off leash because of the occasional drops from the river or service roads but they still enjoyed their time.

WOW! the steps for buttermilk Falls up are pretty strenuous but definitely worth it. The whole gorge is made up of waterfall after waterfall cascades. I would say moderate/easy. I am four months pregnant and we were able to do the hike. We went a little slower than normal with some stops but it was absolutely do able. I did get stung by a yellow jacket so if you or someone your hiking with is allergic bring an epi pen.
A lovely hike that ended up being a little over 5 miles. Nicely maintained trails. A bit crowded in the beginning but it thins out eventually. The plethora of stairs provided a nice challenge.

WOW! the steps for buttermilk Falls up are pretty awful but definitely worth it. The whole gorge is made up of waterfall after waterfall cascades. I would say moderately strenuous. I am four months pregnant and we were able to do the hike. We went a little slower than normal with some stops but it was absolutely do able. I did get stung by a yellow jacket so if you or someone your hiking with is allergic bring an epi pen.
Beautiful.
Absolutely beautiful views!
Here for the Cayuga 50 with lots of great people. Beautiful area.

Love it here. Great hiking for dogs, even a separate swimming section for them in the large falls swimming area. Busy but not so crazy busy that it’s unenjoyable. Apparently you are not supposed to swim in any other area than the large designated area but we did and so were a lot of other people. It was super fun. Just be aware that you can be fined for it as we were told by a policewoman on the way out.

We liked this hike just fine. It does have several points where you are just walking along a road or through parking lots, which isn’t ideal when looking for a good nature experience. There’s lots of water features and a lot of fun places for kids. The biggest drawback is probably the number of other people on the same hike and in the same area.
Best maintained trail i've been on in a while. A little touristy and as it got later in the day it got more crowded, but not too terrible. A really great day hike & I'd highly reccomend.
Not very impressed and it’s a lot of up hill and stairs. A lot.

Found a list of amazing parks in the US. Watkins Glen was on that..which spurred our trip to the Ithaca area. we then found several other great trails including this one.  It is definitely moderate hike on both the Gorge side and Rim Trial. The elevation change is 450ft and it goes up pretty rapidly.  There are a lot of stairs on the Gorge side and the Rim trail and pretty steep headed up or down.  We did the Gorge trail past Pinnacle rock to the road and down the Rim trail. We would have done the whole trek if we had more time.  overall great and beautiful park and waterfalls.
Beautiful waterfalls on the Gorge trail turn into a quiet and peaceful forest on the Bear trail. You can then continue around a serene lake and back to the Gorge or Rim trail. Awesome hike!
Was on my NY trail “bucket list” for awhile, went today and loved it.
This is a very popular and scenic falls with a large swimming area at the base of the falls.
The gorge trail is closed for the winter months.
If you start at the opposite end from Buttermilk, the trail is gorgeous and there are very few people.
Nice trail with good scenery.
Winter hiking at its best! Many many many beautiful waterfalls. Bring your camera. I will be back in the spring for more
Easy trail with no technical parts, wide open and simple to follow. Went in January and was still in good condition and easily hikeable until we got to the lake where it was icy.
hiking on the trail during unseasonably warm weather.

Checked this one out in June of 2017. And this hike doesn’t disappoint! It’s beautiful and moderately well trafficked. Great for all ages. There’s a bit of stairs along the way which are a great way to enter the trail. Awesome views of the falls and rock formations, would definitely go again.
Easy beautiful hike. Fantastic waterfall

I had forgotten how beautiful this hike was.  If you are looking for waterfalls this will definitely fit the bill.  There are a lot of steps so there is a little bit of a workout.  This was the third and final hike while I was down in Ithaca this past weekend, none of them disappointed.  The way out on this one, going around the lake, and taking pictures on the damn on the way back down were definitely highlights.  I can't wait to go camping down in Ithaca again and explore more of the area.
Nice hike with nice views. Decently trafficked on the lower sections, so not the best place for a private peaceful hike.
Gorge hike has numerous falls, steep stair climb at beginning of hike. Well worth the effort. $8 state park entrance fee per car
This is a good hike thru the gorge and views of waterfalls in the area. Well worth your time to try out.

Very good hike. The Gorge trail allows you to get close to several unique waterfalls. It begins with a few long-ish staircases, but the effort here is totally worth it. The Bear Trail is a quiet forested hike with some easy rolling hills. The Lake Treman loop is above the lakeside water level and has a few moderate hills and a couple long staircases. Nice wildflowers on both the Bear trail and the Lake Treman loop, but if you're pressed for time, the Gorge trail is not to be missed.
This hike is very beautiful up and around the falls that eventually you can walk along the gorge. We had rain the last 2 miles but helped cool us off.
First time for my fiance and I at the fingerlakes. Probably the best trail we went on for our time up here! The first stretch was difficult with the stairs but soo worth it!
Beautiful! Make sure you go all the way to the very top

This is an amazing hike. The beginning is tough as it is a basically a quarter mile flight of stairs. However, the climb is totally worth it with each pool and waterfall more beautiful than the next. The bear trail portion leaves the gorge and follows the stream. The trail is well maintained and markings are easy to follow. You can make the trail a loop by crossing the gorge in one of two locations to hit the rim trail. We choose to stick to the Gorge trail.
My first time on this part of the trail. It was gorgeous and charming. The view changes every few steps!

This was a very nice trail with lots of different scenery to enjoy along the trail. We started out early but mid morning the weather got very hot, hazy and humid. Take lots of hydration if you plan to hike this during the late summer months. The water pools are amazing in the morning sun.
Beautiful walk with lots of gorges to enjoy and sit and waid into

Went there late February. Unfortunately the trail that travels along the falls was closed due to ice. Still a nice stop in the winter if you are in the Ithaca area. If you have to travel wait till Spring/Summer.
A waterfall? Try several. Absolutely stunning. Probably 10 waterfalls on this trail alone
A peaceful getaway with Ithaca city limits. And a pretty good climb to get started.

The hike is extremely steep for the first half a mile or so, but it flattens out a bit once you get going. When the river is drier, you can walk across to the other side and explore, or just follow the river itself upstream. It's beautiful hike!
this was so much fun. long hike lots of up hill very beautiful
Lots of steps, but worth the climb. Not much water flowing, but still a very beautiful and enjoyable hike.
Short but pretty not as nice as Robert h treman

VERY enjoyable and beautiful!! The stairs are definitely a climb and a bit challenging if you're an asthmatic like me but the climb is SOOO worth it. There are several waterfalls along with natural pools (careful though the rock floor can be slippery) overall I loved the time that was spent here.
Gorgeous falls and a really well maintained trails
Very nice hike! People jump in the water at different points! I am not that adventurous and will not be trying that any time soon!
Simply a great trail
Too bad there is a drought in the area, it would be fanatastic. But now only a little stream...
The falls were amazing! There are a lot of stairs but you can bypass a lot of them by going to the lower park entrance
My favorite place on Earth❤️
I'm loving this one
A lot of stairs....but worth it for the views.
Beautiful gorge hike. NY is experiencing a bit of a drought so the falls were not that impressive. However, the gorge itself is well worth the hike.
Just gorgeous, family friendly, a must visit if you're in Ithaca. Did it at least three times while in Ithaca.

Cloudy cool day but perfect for a hike. Not too busy, but very busy in the summer. The gorge trail is nearly all steps and the rim trail back down is gentle sloping. Beautiful falls and pools along the way.
very nice.
The trail is very scenic with some tough spots.  We made it with a 7 & 10 year old.
Beautiful
Nice hike with beautiful view of waterfalls

This is our favorite hike in CNY.  Absolutely LOVED it.  It kept getting better as we walked deeper.  The stairs at the beginning were pretty steep but once you got past them the rest was smooth sailing.  LOVE!!!
This trail is awesome! The waterfalls were beautiful!
Good trails. Walked up Gorge trail, Bear trail, around the lake and back.
Great trails! George Trail has amazing views!
Beautiful, my 5 year old did it. I would suggest starting early because it gets really busy.
Nice hike, with beautiful views. Wish gorge trail was open all the way through!!
Good hike a few stairs to say the least
Even during a thunderstorm Buttermilk Falls State Park is still a great hike and always beautiful!

The falls are beautiful. One of the busier trails. I would recommend going during the week or early morning. Relatively short hike but the gorge trail is a bit steep and challenging at times so still a good workout!
A classic NY state park trail.  Beautiful, scenic hiking.  Moderate difficulty with lots of stairs.  Love to hike this and then go to Ithaca Beer Company to relax
A nice walk with a lot of stairs. Beautiful Falls.
My fiance and I went here fall of 2014.  Beautiful trail and well maintained.  Go early to avoid crowds
Hike here. The falls are gorgeous and the trails are well maintained. Just don't camp. It's right smack dab in the city of Ithaca so at night all you here are the wonderful sounds of highways
First time to upstate New York and it didn't disappoint. It's amazing how lush the trail is. We hiked up Bear Trail to Treman Lake and down Rim Trail. Easy, beautiful hike.

I was on a girls' trip to NYC then to Syracuse.  After being in NYC for a few days we needed some fresh air!  I love being outside but we had one or two girls who were not the outdoor pros but even they really enjoyed this hike.  We started first on the Rim trail down to the falls then went back up the Gorge Trail.  The Gorge trail has a better view of the falls but both trails together make a loop.  The falls were very pretty and seemed to go on and on!  Very pretty moderate hike, but with some stairs on the Gorge trail.

We walked from the base of the falls up the Gorge Trail and then back along the Rim Trail. The falls are beautiful, even though the water level was very low. You can swim at the base of the falls where there is a life guard and picnic area which we did. The water was COLD as you'd expect but we had a great time.
good times

Loved this park. While Gorge trail had the most to offer in terms of versatility and views, Treman Lake had some amazing spots as well. Make sure the swimming portion is open if going on a hot day. The rest of the reviews hit it on the head except for Brickman's, which completely misses the mark. Overall, this was a great day spot with sufficient off trail accessibility to keep even experienced hikers engaged. Would visit again for sure.
A lot of great views and rocks and tons of waterfalls. Gorge Trail is the best. Also, Brickman doesn't know what he is talking about.
4/18/2014.  The gorge trail is still closed due to patches of snow and ice along the path....

This is another nice hike in Ithaca.  We went up the Rim trail, then onto the Bear trail, up to Treman Lake. Then doubled back and came down the Gorge Trail.  If you only have time for one trail, do the Gorge Trail, it has the best scenic (gorge/waterfalls) view.  We went midweek in November and rarely encountered another hiker.  There is a really nice picnic area with grills and tables up by Treman Lake.  I never knew the lake or picnic area existed.

We completed 3 of the 4 trails in about an hour and forty minutes. We started at the base of Rim then did the Bear trail before doubling back and finishing with Gorge trail. The Rim trail starts you off right away with a good incline, the trail was well maintained and we saw a few deer and snakes! Not much as far as view on Rim, but it was a nice hike. Bear Trail was pretty easy, not much if any incline/decline so it's a nice change of pace from both Rim and/or Gorge. Gorge trail was beautiful and nice to be doing on the way back as I prefer stairs going down than up. If you want to do stairs up and trail coming down then I would suggest you start with Gorge and come back on Rim .
Not sure how to delete my review below. I thought I was on Taughannock Falls. Sorry everyone :)
Great hike long set of stairs from the bottom great falls!

I very much enjoyed this trail. It isn't as spectacular as some of the nearby gorges (Treman Park, Watkins Glen), but still plenty worth the trip. The trail is decently well kept and affords some nice views. It's a popular park: even with the weather being in the low 40s, there were lots of people (and dogs). You'll only find an agressive incline in the northern most part (near the falls) - so people looking for an easy hike can easily drive to the back parking lot and still hike most of it.

Amazing Gorge Trail.  The water was a little dry on the falls.  I heard that Spring is the best time of the year to view the falls.  When the water is gushing down the falls.  There is a cave inside one of the canyons that have a water fall in it.

I have been to Buttermilk Falls state Park many times. Nice place to hike with nice views of the falls. It is not a place to go if you want to be secluded. There are usually a good amount of people there but still a nice trail. Not a difficult hike, good for children and dogs.

Taughannock Falls Gorge Trail.Name: Taughannock Falls Gorge Trail

parking lot: NY 89, eight miles north of Ithaca to the Main Entrance.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Use of firearms for deer hunting is not allowed. Bow hunting may be allowed. BE SAFE: See the specific trail owner/steward’s website for the most up to date details

Reviews.comment: Clean, easy with a stroller and plenty of places to stop and rest or enjoy the view.
Beautiful reward at the end of a gentle short hike
My personal favorite.  Super easy and well maintained, with beautiful waterfalls at the end.
Quick and easy. The size of the gorge walls are breathtaking

My husband and I did this trail with our dog on 3-27-21.  We have done this trail before, but the waterfall was just a trickle then, so we wanted to see it at a time when it had more water flowing.  It is a very easy, flat walk to the waterfall and back, and more crowded than we like, but I think that's typical here.  The scenery is beautiful throughout the walk with some education posted along the way, which is always very interesting.   The waterfall was gorgeous, and full of water.   I really hate to be around a lot of people in nature and honestly almost rated it a 3 solely for that reason, but we knew what to expect before we came.  --Jennifer

Easy stroll through a beautiful canyon that reminded me a bit of Zion. The trip along the river and the falls at the end are absolutely amazing too. The very end was closed at the end of the bridge, but still cool to get so close to such a tall waterfall!
Did both loops and saw two beautiful falls.
Nice short hike withe beautiful views!
Great short hike￼
A nice easy hike. Great for the family. The falls were beautiful. They are really flowing this time of year.￼ You’ll love the scenery as you walk to the falls as well￼.

easy trail/more of a nature walk, gets packed with big groups so that was kind of frustrating. but it's easy enough that it was a nice walk as a blizzard was picking up and the waterfall is beautiful in the winter
Trail was a bit icy but really good overall.  Not too steep at any spot and wide trail.
If you have ever thought about seeing the falls in winter now is the time. Absolutely gorgeous but you can’t go past the end of the bridge near the falls.
It was icy but easily walked
It was cold (20F), but turned out to be a very nice walk back to the falls with my kids. The path was well cleared of snow and wasn’t slippery for the most part.
I went out 2 days ago. The trail to the bottom of the falls was packed, powder snow. It wasn’t icy at  all. Beautiful walk.
Great little hike to the falls
Nice Sunday afternoon hike. Water was running great which made beautiful ice structures
Easy hike but absolutely stunning views. Went in October and the foliage was breathtaking. So peaceful. Also the only state park in Ithaca that’s free (always a plus!)
Easy trail with views the whole way. Went on a Sunday and wasn’t even that busy and the falls were raging! Absolutely beautiful. Super cold and icy near the falls so be prepared.
Absolutely beautiful here!
nice easy trail! just a bit muddy in some areas and lots of ice closer to the end where the waterfall is, recommended good boots or shoes with traction.
North Rim Trail stairs close in winter, just take the marked alternate route up to the campground and it connects back to the trail.
Super easy trail. Went on an icy weather that made the stretch near the falls a bit slippery which is to be expected. The view of the Taughannock falls was breath taking.
Icy at the falls... wear your spikes!
Trail was easy and straightforward, the waterfall was gorgeous!
The trail was well cleared after the snow and was very clean and easy to follow. Just a little over a mile long trail so it was pretty short, but very flat and beautiful
completely private moment!
This is a beautiful spot, a gem of upstate. Many thanks to the people of NY from an Oklahoman passing through!
We did North ridge, down the gorge trail, and then back to the parking lot via south ridge. All trails said it was about 6 miles total. I think that’s a little exaggerated, but it’s a better gauge.
What a beautiful gorge trail for any season , the falls at the end are spectacular

last call for the Rim Trails before they close for the winter! get on out here!  the Gorge Trail stays open year-round.  Stay on the main trails, hunting is allowed in season on the Multi-Use area by Rice Hill.
Very easy trail to a spectacular waterfall.

Nicely maintained, heavily trafficked trail. Saw people with strollers, walkers, wheelchairs, young and old. Gorgeous water views. We parked near the gorge overlook and walked down using the north rim trail. Used the VERY steep steps to get up and down. They were ever so slightly uneven, each step a different height, but manageable. There was another option to get down. Highly recommend!
crowded in the gorge
Came early at 6. I was alone at the Falls. The gorge and the falls are extremely beautiful!
Crowded but still beautiful

Beautiful as always. Very little water over the falls, but it's always a pleasant walk. Very easy, wide and well maintained path. Get there early in the morning to avoid the crowds, especially on nice weekend days.

Started on the south rim trail heading towards Cayuga Lake. Once crossing the Gorge Trail we decided to walk down to get a close view of the waterfall, but the best view was on the North Rim trail portion of the loop where there is a great overlook. Fairly easy hike with some steep portions and one big flight of steps up to the North Rim trail. There are also picnic tables for a quick snack break down by Cayuga Lake at the halfway point of the loop.

Quiet and peaceful on a weekday morning (8-10am). Lower lot full by 10:30. ￼ Started by base of gorge then up <1 mile on wide uphill path to visitor center on N rim to get the hard stuff out of the way. Best rim trail in the area with lots of great views. Go to one overlook past the visitor center then turn around. Gorge trail was beautiful and very diff than others in the area. The falls are spectacular.

This was a perfect hike in the fall! I know the waterfall is all the hype but the actually trail is very beautiful and well maintained with plenty of scenic views throughout! Although popular, everyone was still very respectful and kept their distance. All in all I was very happy with it!
Over crowded. The falls are nice when flowing but so many people..
Easy, flat and beautiful scenery
Do the South Trail - North Trail Loop if you can

Great fall hike with foliage towards evening closing time of the main parking area(6$). Did not have time for the longer rim loop trails. Can walk the  flat rock river bed also right upto the base of the falls off trail.
Easy and nice. If you have limited time, I preferred Treman State Park. Not a ton of water in the waterfall, but nice fall colors on the short hike there. Would get more stars in the spring, I think!
The trail itself through george is very nice but the falls are not impressive. Water is barely there
Stunning and easy waterfall hike.
the water in the falls is a bit low in the autumn, but still a breathtaking walk being surrounded by cliffs and lovely fall colors.
Beautiful limestone formations! Saw a snake and some chipmunks. Definitely explore the riverbed!

Very, very easy trail. Mostly paved or light gravel fill. Sadly, water is low currently so falls aren't full nor is river. Beautiful fall scenery though. Mostly everyone was wearing masks. Easy path for dogs. FYI, there's a fee to park on weekends.
Easy Trail to Explore
Beautiful!
Super easy trail but not much in terms of views. I'd recommend doing the upper rim trail for a more interesting and slightly harder trek

Completed the rim trails (north to south) and the gorge trail. Other than the steps and a short inclined stretch at the beginning, pretty easy and family friendly. Took away a star for the lack of a falls (it's been a dry month) and the mobs of people everywhere, half of which completely ignored the mask requirements. Recommendation for this time of year? Go on a weekday. Fall colors were pretty though.

Started at overlook and took North rim trail. It crosses a bridge and then you’re on the South rim trail. It wasn’t obvious but the end of the South rim trail takes you all the way to the bottom. We hiked up the gorge trail to see the falls area. No real water flowing today but the foliage was great!  Hike back to start if Gorge trail.
