More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: excellent smowshoe hike
Great hike.  Beautiful trail.   Snowshoes used,  although not needed.  Cross country trails are pretty packed down.   Snowshoes make it easy to step off to allow the skiers to pass.
my dog and I really enjoyed this trail. it was very open and clear. I am not sure which loop we ended up doing but there were a ton of options. A beautiful morning in the woods!
OK hike. Nothing to exciting or interesting, but a peaceful walk in the woods.
so pretty and quiet!

This was a gorgeous trail, so many beautiful sights! Found it kind of hard to find the trail head so basically I would suggest parking in the very open parking lot to the right once you get the the location, and just crossing the road! It was pretty empty to me, but I also just came after a rain storm so that may have been why. Definitely want to come back and explore more of the trails here!

This is an underrated gem. The trail is well-marked with NYSDEC markers. It passes through many different kinds of forests and there is wonderful alpine scenery. All of the other trails in this trail network are also very good and hikers have the option of doing just a short walk but there are other possibilities for 10+ mile routes.
A few steep spots for beginners but nothing you can’t walk if necessary. Great trail!
great trail easy to get lost in your thoughts on this trail
Trails are very well maintained pleasant hike but I can't see it as a moderate hike, easy at most.
It has mountain biking trails as well, lots of hill, lots if mud, tons if fun :)
Easy but slightly confusing trail markers. Be sure you take a map or you could easily get lost.

Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

parking lot: Parking lot on Hammond Hill Rd before seasonal use road

Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: excellent smowshoe hike
Great hike.  Beautiful trail.   Snowshoes used,  although not needed.  Cross country trails are pretty packed down.   Snowshoes make it easy to step off to allow the skiers to pass.
my dog and I really enjoyed this trail. it was very open and clear. I am not sure which loop we ended up doing but there were a ton of options. A beautiful morning in the woods!
OK hike. Nothing to exciting or interesting, but a peaceful walk in the woods.
so pretty and quiet!

This was a gorgeous trail, so many beautiful sights! Found it kind of hard to find the trail head so basically I would suggest parking in the very open parking lot to the right once you get the the location, and just crossing the road! It was pretty empty to me, but I also just came after a rain storm so that may have been why. Definitely want to come back and explore more of the trails here!

This is an underrated gem. The trail is well-marked with NYSDEC markers. It passes through many different kinds of forests and there is wonderful alpine scenery. A few steep spots for beginners but nothing you can’t walk if necessary. Great trail!
great trail easy to get lost in your thoughts on this trail
Trails are very well maintained pleasant hike but I can't see it as a moderate hike, easy at most.
It has mountain biking trails as well, lots of hill, lots if mud, tons if fun :)
Easy but slightly confusing trail markers. Be sure you take a map or you could easily get lost.

Finger Lakes Trail - Hammond Hill FLT.Description: The Hammond Hill State Forest Multiple Use Trail System has been designed to offer family-based recreation for hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding, and cross-county skiing. More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Trail Markers: finger lakes trail blazes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Great area for snowshoeing and x-country skiing without being too crowded. Large parking area directly from trailhead. Tons of side trails, so if you get off track, you'll find a way back. Some smaller side trails on the map were covered in snow, but they are there and waiting to be broken!
Well marked, easy to cut shorter or longer
Super! Loved this trail. Lots of distant views through the trees, and the big radio tower was nifty too.
Bring a mask!  Be considerate!
Great trail with parking lots on both ends. Saw some larger trees and an interesting old road bed.
Rugged trail to start, got better as we got going.
Simple hike. Little boring but a decent outing

Great hike... a few moderately steep sections. As another reviewer mentioned, be sure to have your GPS, as the hike traverses several different trails in Hammond Hill and it would be otherwise impossible to follow the route.

Need to get some updated trail maps for this awesome chunk of state land. Great hike, great day. Don't go without gps or good map/compass skills if you are unfamiliar with HH. You'll still have a great hike but it's hard to follow this route without.

Shindagin Hollow R1.Name: Shindagin Hollow R1
Shindagin Hollow R1.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow R4.Name: Shindagin Hollow R4
Shindagin Hollow R4.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow Y1.Name: Shindagin Hollow Y1
Shindagin Hollow Y1.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow Y4.Name: Shindagin Hollow Y4
Shindagin Hollow Y4.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!

Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow Y9.Name: Shindagin Hollow Y9
Shindagin Hollow Y9.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.

Shindagin Hollow B3.Name: Shindagin Hollow B3
Shindagin Hollow B3.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd and on Shindagin Hollow Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow B7.Name: Shindagin Hollow B7
Shindagin Hollow B7.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd and on Shindagin Hollow Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.

Tough climb to start but generally flat with only minor elevation changes once on the loop.  Not many views but a very enjoyable outing no less.  The only hikers I saw were on Shindagin Rd at the beginning of my hike but I moved off the path regularly once onto the loop for mountain bikers.
Nice trail. A little confusing in one part- ended up off trail but got back on quickly. A good steep climb in the beginning. Not too bad coming back down at the end.

We tried to go on a short hike with the dogs and ended up doing about a mile of the white trail. I wish we had looked up a trail map ahead of time bc it sounds like some others have gone on great short dog hikes. We followed this trail and it was disappointing. Mostly uphill, no water, no views, really buggy.
Be careful in the wooden bridge. Angry yellow jackets live under it.  I do NOT think that this trail is easy... the first uphill climb is STEEP!!!  The rest is beautiful and rolling.

This is a very pretty trail. Once you leave the Finger Lakes Trail portion, though, it isn’t very well marked. Couple that with the fact that the area is crisscrossed by a  myriad of trails helps to explain why this 5.8 mile hike ended up 7+ miles long. Thank goodness AllTrails kept alerting us to wrong turns!

pretty nice area, trails firm and dense forest. website says you can park anywhere you want on the gravel roads here, and people were. there is a few turnaround/pulloff type parking spots, and small dirt lots at major junctions and exits scattered about. Massive amounts of berries and medicinals
Wonderful hiking trail that also doubles as an experienced mountain biking trail. Saw about 10 different trail riders.

Very lovely trail! We did as someone else suggested and parked slightly north where the Jeep Trail starts. There is plenty of parking and the seasonal road is in good condition. This route definitely cuts the steepness, but there is still a nice, steady incline to get to the looped trail.  Markers could be better. I recommend downloading the map ahead of time so you don't miss a turn. The trail is in great condition and there was very limited mud today even though it rained two days ago. Bugs weren't an issue today, but it was also cooler today compared with the rest of the week.  We saw about 6 groups of people. Two were backpacking the FLT, three mountain biking groups, and one other hiker. Since mountain bikes are common, it's probably a good idea to keep your dog leashed. My dogs loved it. I have a 9 year old collie and a 3 year old Australian Shepherd and both did great.

The hill from Prospect Valley road was the only part of the hike I disliked. Going up of course but also going down at the return trip. We have had a lot of rain these past few days so the mud on some parts of the trail was expected. I would be cautious with young children on the edge of the ravine as it is very steep! A few creek crossings got our feet slightly wet but not impassable. Had no cell service the whole walk. Bugs were bad only when we stopped. Used bug spray and didn't discover any ticks.  Very pleasant day. Enjoyed being outdoors!!
More moderate than easy.
Very lots of black flys.  Bug spray a must. Trail is in good shape but lots of mud from run off.  Liked this trail a lot.
muddy and lots of water to cross but a great hike!!!
easy and scenic.

I suggest starting where trail 1 hits the Jeep trail a bit north from where this says to start on the finger lakes trail.  The starting point listed here is sometimes muddy and always a steep climb to get to the loop.
A little muddy, but nothing all that bad if you have hiking boots. We took the suggested AT route and it was a nice hike. A few hills, but nothing overly exerting if you're in ok shape.
Not as easy as it is rated...
FLT Shindagan Hollow, quite muddy, beautiful woods, moderate hike
First time hiking this was a bit of an experience, the bugs were bad but was a great hike overall. Will try different trails next time
good hike for the first day of spring with the doggo
Excellent. cant wait to go back and explore more.
Great trail.
Yes! Bears Do shit in the wood! Saw a fresh paw print that REALLY got me moving! Had to be 700 pounder!
Bears, we found do NOT always hibernate! 600lbs we guess! Moved REAL FAST after that!
Just beautiful. Can be as easy or difficult as you want. Some trails are very steep, some are old Jeep roads!

Beautiful hike! I'll be back soon to take advantage of the fire pit and lean to (about 3/4 miles in). Lovely small waterfalls and a few old stone remnants of houses. The trail is usually well marked, but I found myself guessing at times. Great scenery, would recommend

Beautiful woods and the trails are not too muddy in Mid-June. Be sure to download the map trails as the signal for mobile phones is too poor there. Small, lovely waterfalls good for wading. Also go through the AllTrails app to find the trailhead, Google maps will send you into the middle of nowhere! There was a nice lean-to for overnights, and the whole thing was very nicely maintained. I just wish we had had the map, because we were just guessing. We'll be back better prepared!

I'd rate this trail Easy to Moderate compared to Breakneck Ridge (Hard) and Mount Hadley (Moderate). The trail is not too steep, and with an even surface throughout. There's many variations that could upgrade it's difficulty to Medium-Hard because of very steep sections but definitely there's no scrambling involved. However, the scenery is beautiful, and I encountered lots of wild life such as deer. Trails are not well marked in several sections so I'd recommend bringing a map or a compass just in case. I'd definitely do it again because of the many variations that it offers and because of it's low traffic (I didn't encounter anyone on my Saturday morning hike)

I loved this place.  Great scenery and enough elevation difference to consider it a real hike.  I didn't do the loop trail when I was there.  Did an out and back one but I found a nice area for pitching a tent a little ways in where there was also a lean to.  Altogether I got in about a 7.5 mile hike and I'm looking forward to going back to do the rest.
I recommend entering the park through Prospect Valley Road, especially if you have a vehicle that's low to the ground.
Climbed today 3/6/14 great hike.   Little icy still but great to get out there!!
A cool fall day but a nice hike in the woods!
Completed again on 4/6/2013 on a beautiful spring day!  A very nice trail not always well marked and at the time still icy... Will do it again though.

First of all it is marked WRONG on this website. Other then that this is one of the best trails I have every been on. I would give it 5 stars but the trails need to be marked out better. I even had a map on my phone and still got a little lost. Who ever works this trail system does a very good job.
This is an excellent trail. Slightly challenging but very enjoyable

Shindagin Hollow C2.Name: Shindagin Hollow C2
Shindagin Hollow C2.Description: Shindagin Hollow State Forest is a well known place for mountain bicycling. Twenty miles of mountain bike trails are maintained through a DEC Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with Cycle-CNY, an International Mountain Bicycling Association (IMBA) affiliated club.  The Finger Lakes Hiking Trail (FLT) also crosses the forest providing a well marked hiking trail in a forest setting. About 5.7 miles of the FLT is on Shindagin Hollow State Forest and is maintained through an Volunteer Stewardship Agreement with the Cayuga Trails Club and the Finger Lakes Trails Conference.  Four miles of snowmobile trail cross the forest and are maintained by the Candor Valley Rider Snowmobile Club through a Volunteer Stewardship Agreement.  Horseback riding is prohibted on this forest.  Also consider using the State Lands Interactive Mapper available on the DEC website at http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/45415.html to view the current recreational opportunities on State Forests.

street: Parking Lot on Braley Hill Rd and on Shindagin Hollow Rd

More Info: Part of interconnected trail system: Yes
Hunting is allowed on this trail - use caution.

Reviews.comment: Love it
Awesome!!

This is one of my favorite trails I have done this far. I first came in the spring when the creeks were over following and the trail lead you right throw them. They are dried up now and parts of the trail a little over grown, plus some trees have fallen causing the trail to divert a little. Still a fun challenge highly recommend!

Peaceful and remote. The FLT goes up fairly steeply from the road, and follows a ridge line for awhile with great forest views. The blue/green/yellow trails are sparsely marked and a bit confusing. They take just a bit of faith but are generally easy to follow (at least the green 2 trail is). Parts of the green 2 trail are quite steep going downhill, which I imagine would be pretty fun on a mountain bike. At top of hill near the junction between the FLT and the DEC colored markers there’s a nice place for campfires.  The FLT passes what looks to be a very old stone cabin in the woods. Great area for exploring. We’ll be back. Bonus: a giant patch of lycopods!
